* The music was enjoyable, but not amazing. But I'm not here for the music.
* The art was quite good. All the sprites are really good looking as are the monster portraits. The world is almost always enjoyable to look at, I tend to like the out door areas better than the dungeons, but even the worst area is at least fine.
* Very stable. I never crashed once and I didn't see any bugs bigger than some short term visual glitching.
* Depth. Each monster gets a nice Diablo 2 talent tree and can often be built in a couple different ways. There are a little over 100 monsters and each gets two palette swapped/shiny versions, each with different stats and abilities, making the roster feel much bigger than it looks. A light side monster built to be a healer looks and plays differently than a dark side damage dealer, even if they are the same species.
* The combat is turned base and a little awkward sometimes, but I really do like it. Some people complain that it's too hard, but I really didn't find that to be the case. Actually I found it pretty easy, with a few exceptions. Monsters scale their level to yours the first time you enter a new area, so nothing ever out levels you and nothing should be too easy, unless you grind a bunch extra. Actually the boss was easy enough that I assumed there was another boss, until after the credits started rolling.

149348114.review:
Really fun and unique take on the collector/battler type of game. The exploration/metroidvania aspect was pretty fun, too and was a neat way to explore the map. Building teams is probably the most fun part, however, I wish there was more incentive in a normal play through to do so. Once you find a build that works, you're pretty much set, aside from some tweaks as you progress. The post game battles are fun and the method for saving/loading teams is really great because it saves the gear too which helps to minimize the gear upgrades for making multiple teams. So, if you force yourself to try out new teams, that would enrich the experience. When you get to a certain story part ([spoiler]unlocking shifting[/spoiler]), it really ramps up the options for synergies.

Leveling is handled pretty well, and eventually I just decided to focus on leveling my main team to max/near max and then just hatch new eggs - since the new monsters are close to your max level (usually 2-3 behind).

I finished a full play through and while I overdid it a bit, I do look forward to coming back trying the alternate modes, such as bravery, which makes it so you get a random assortment of monsters, which will make a unique team building challenge.

I didn't get to try any pvp - it seems there's an active discord for doing so, but you won't find matches without coordination.

Also the music in most cases is really great, some reminiscent of Castlevania, and really adds to the exploration feel. However, there were some volume inconsistencies and a few tracks that stuck out - not bad necessarily but with so many great tracks, the lesser ones were more noticeable to me. Those are just my nitpicks, your ears won't have a bad time.

I'll admit, there were times I did get a bit overwhelmed with all the possibilities and resorted to looking things up to help (such as on the wiki, to see what other monsters shared certain skills, etc). But even then, part of that was the fun for me, figuring out the puzzle of team building. If you're into team building, synergies, exploration in a 2-D platformer, this fits a unique niche, going well above just a "pokemon clone". I greatly look forward to Moi Rai Games next title!

If you like pokemon and deck-building (e,g, slay the spire) games, you should 100% get this one.

TL;DR: Absolutely amazing deck-building combat mechanics; in a lackluster platforming/metroidvania overworld shell.

The good: The combat in this game is simply amazing: very well designed and diverse monsters, with team synergy being a must in the later stages of the game. The developers managed to make every single one of the 100+ monsters usable in this game, which is a balancing marvel. I 100% support the meme that this is pokemon done right. The difficulty wall that many players mention when reaching the later parts of the game is because that's when team synergy becomes a requirement to surpass the final challenges. If you're lazy, just go with the obvious goblin route and you should be fine.

The bad: Platforming feels somewhat half baked, so don't expect to derive gameplay pleasure from that. The metroidvania aspect is just... meh. Did you think that the HMs aspect in pokémon was fun? Yeah, me neither. You quickly learn that you're forced to capture specific mons to get past some barriers and then you just  accept it and do it. You constantly need to switch mons because "OK fine I'll get the stone breaking mon and then the darkness seeing mon". Exploration is bland: it typically rewards you with 100s of chests with just materials to upgrade weapons and nothing more - you rarely get unique weapons or deep secrets. So the metroidvania just fills like a boring filler when compared to the absolutely amazing combat system in this game.

Got the game on sale for like 6 bucks, and having completed it I’d say it’s PROBABLY worth $15, maybe. If you play through the content normally there’s about 20 hours of game, and I did a bunch of the side content and none of the post game so I’m guessing there’s maybe 30-35 hours of total content in here. And an online mode I never touched!

First and foremost the game is just a turn based RPG. The UI is mostly functional, stats are mostly easy to understand, and the fundamental gameplay loop of “go to new area, collect monsters that let you get to newer area, repeat’ is fairly fun. It has a lot more in common with the old Final Fantasy/classical turn based RPG games and Aria of Sorrow than it does Pokemon though. Don’t buy the game expecting Pokemon because it definitely isn’t that.

That being said, on a lot of fronts the game is fairly mediocre. The exploration parts are carried extremely hard by the only interesting thing being finding new monsters to collect. The art is pretty underwhelming. The new environments are all extremely generic. Apart from maybe the monster designs there’s nothing really inspired or creative about any of the assets. The plot is entirely forgettable. The absolute worst thing about the game is the music, which is ALWAYS playing, is far too short so you hear it loop constantly, and is very annoying. You can turn sound off for the entire game and your experience will be better off for it. 

When playing everything that isn’t a battle I was pretty dissatisfied as well. There are maybe 3 or 4 tricky platforming sections but every other ‘puzzle’ in the game is laughably easy. Exploration is a joke, there’s almost no reason to explore each area after you’ve collected all the monsters in it because all you’re doing is picking up items you can probably just buy with all the gold you aren’t spending anyway. I never really had a use for 95% of the items I picked up. Battles take a significant amount of time, even when your max level dudes are fighting level 1 clowns, so later on you’ll just be dodging fights entirely and that makes backtracking to old areas a real chore. It doesn’t seem intentional but there are an awful lot of design choices that seem to pad out the playtime quite a bit. At least there’s a fast travel item!

Where the game really shines is its battle system. In a lot of the later game fights there’s so much random nonsense flying around on screen it can be kind of hard to discern what precisely is going on, but despite that the game does a good job with its UI elements to let you know which monsters are causing which problems to you, and it’s up to you to decide what is and isn’t a priority. The difficulty is pretty well tuned most of the time, I could regularly beat bosses and enemies about 2 levels higher than my own. Anything higher than that and there’s a good chance you’ll get absolutely creamed though. Customizing your party members via the perk tree feels very nice, although in the endgame your dudes are going to have like 75% of the tree anyway so you’re usually only making important choices in the midgame. Leveling up is done automatically for new monsters you acquire so there’s not TOO much grinding, but I did do some at the end of the game because I wanted to see what those level 40 perks were (they’re not important or interesting, I wouldn’t bother). This part of the game functionally carries everything else- if the battles were a bit worse, I definitely would have dropped it after maybe 10 hours.

Overall this feels almost like a dated game. It’s hard to believe it came out in 2020 because it feels very reminiscent of an RPG I'd might have played on the GameBoy, and I don’t mean that as a compliment. There definitely are better turn based RPGs you could be playing, but for its price point I think it’s not a bad way to spend a weekend.

I don't think I've ever played a game where the ratio of how I wanted to like it vs the amount I actually enjoyed was so high. On paper, this should be the perfect game for me; how could I not love a creature collector metroidvania? Unfortunately, this game serves as a good reminder that putting two different styles of game together is not a simple task by any means. The two feel at odds with one another, if anything.

Even on the lowest difficulty, it feels like the game expects you to perfectly understand every single mechanic and stat like competitive Pokémon, without the terabytes of easily accessible data compiled over 20 years. Combine that with some really annoying menu design and far, far too much gear and individual stats and I found myself more annoyed than anything just trying to get through the game.

It's a shame, because there's so much promise in this game, but it misses the mark just enough to make me think twice about whether or not I can comfortably recommend it. 145666867.review:
[b]# QUICK REVIEW FOR WHOEVER WANTS TO GIVE | MONSTER SANCTUARY A TRY | #[/b]

[b]Monster Sanctuary is a monster-tamer game that managed to pull me in by adding metroidvania elements to it's core![/b]

I'll go over a bit of it's general mechanisms and how they fare throughout the whole game until you beat it.

[b]# GAMEPLAY # | 8 /10[/b]

The game play revolves around various elements that make it stand out from other games of this genre. You're basically exploring as a 2DMetroidvania-like since you can use the abilities on the environment of the monsters that you have captured. This makes the exploration aspect of the game quite rewarding as it makes you want to check the monster encyclopedia in order to see if it's worth capturing X and Y monsters because of their abilities.
The combat is a turn-based 3V3 where your monsters take part in and you're basically there to give them directions on what to do, and use some items to! The combat is incredibly fun because the focus this time around wasn't on capturing 1000 monsters and hoping for the one with the best stats. In turn, you get to several skill trees you can choose from to learn skills, reset at any time (with an item) and experiment with!
This makes for a super entertaining and engaging combat, since you'll be wanting to create synergies between your monsters.

What I think that in terms of gameplay the game lacked at the end of the line was a deeper and larger world to explore! Don't get me wrong, the map is quite big. Although eventually you'll be going over the same places to unlock specific hidden paths, or doors.

[b]# STORY # | 7.5 /10[/b]
(SPOILER FREE)

This was a hard one to evaluate as IMHO the core story of the game is very solid. Every bit of story that is added seems to connect. There's always this sense of wanting to know more as you progress through the storyline!
The foundation, the roots of the story are there. Everything sounds plausible and you do get that sense of adventure as you follow your hero's path, however the only downside I found was that at the end I was still left with a wild sense and want to unravel many other mysteries that were "out there".

[b]# VISUALS # | 9 /10[/b]

Great pixel art, detailed monsters splash art, fluid animations, many visually captivating environments and amazing SFXs during combat! What else can I say? The team did a phenomenal work in terms of finding the right aesthetics for their retro monster taming game. Think if Castlevania SOTN was mixed with DS gen Pokemon games. Neat!

[b]# Sound # 7 /10[/b]

While the visuals and story are something that will definitely stay on my mind for a while, I can't say the same about the music. Yes, the retro feel is there and, yes the boss battle music is good. What I feel was a bit of a disappointment was the lack of variation in music for battles fought on the different environments. I feel like this would add a lot to the game.
Maybe this didn't happen because of the need to have a larger world in order to justify having a battle theme song for every biome.

[b]# OVERALL SCORE # 8/10[/b]

All in all, Monster Sanctuary is a great 2D platformer that somehow manages to merge several game mechanisms and still make it a very enjoyable metroidvania monster taming experience!
My experience was quite positive with the game, although I feel like I should point out a few Pros and Cons for you to help you decide whether you buy the game, or not!

[b]PROS:[/b]

- Solid gameplay (exploration & battle-wise).
- Freedom of creativity to adjust each monster's build according to your gameplay style.
- Many small good QOLs such as: Battle speed adjuster; Difficulty switcher; Useful teleportation items;
- Game is small and runs great on desktop, laptop or even on a Steam Deck.
- Original take on the mechanisms resulting in a great Pokevania experience.

[b]CONS:[/b]

- [spoiler]Somehow the last boss fight's difficulty spikes HARD-CORE. Even if you do sidequests, I'm positive that you'll need to grind and find an incredibly good synergy on your team to win this fight! I switched to Casual difficulty to bypass unnecessary grind. [/spoiler]
- The replay-ability factor is not that great unless you really want to try PvP, or grind on.
- The evolutions feel a bit confusing and most times you find yourself using items on all monsters to try and evolve them, instead of actually trying to use something that makes sense.
- The lore of the game is great which makes me believe that the game is way to short, or they'll be thinking of making Monster Sanctuary II.

143956008.review:
[h1] Overview [/h1]
Monster Sanctuary (MS) is a Metrodvania, creature collector game with a strong focus on tactical, turn-based combat to make use of a unique combo mechanic, buffs, debuffs, and rock/paper/scissor type advantage in order to be victorious. All the creatures have unique, customizable skill trees, and can be equipped with items to boost their stats in a fashion similar to a typical JRPG. The game took me about 57 hours to get 100% of the achievements, including collecting all of the monsters and completing all of the optional challenge battles. A completion of just the critical path would probably take about 25 to 30 hours. I hadn't played a Pokemon game in a long time so I picked up this game to scratch that creature collecting itch, and I imagine many other people looking into this game will be looking into this game for the same reason. Because of that, I will compare MS at times to Pokemon for reference. 

[h1] Combat Overview [/h1]
After a few introductory fights, the player will eventually get a party of 6 Monsters. Whenever the player encounters a enemy they will battle, there will be a pre-battle screen where the player will be able to view their party of 6 monsters versus the enemy monsters (typically 3), as well as each monster's resistances, vulnerabilities, and elemental type for the moves it can use. From this pre-battle screen, the player will select 3 of their 6 monsters to fight the enemy. Victory is often determined at this point by choosing strategically based off of type advantages/resistances. Once battle begins, the player has the freedom to choose the order their 3 monsters will attack in, as well as what abilities/attacks to use for each monster. Once the player's three monsters attack, the enemy does the same with their three monsters. Rinse and repeat until the battle is over. After winning a battle, the player will be given score and a star rating out of 5 (or 6 if you earn a bonus star for being exceptionally efficient) for how effective the player was in the combat. The higher the player's rating, the better quantity and quality of rewards the player gets.

Battles come in 3 varieties:
Wild monster battles: 3 player monsters vs 3 wild enemy monsters.
Champion monster battles: 3 player monsters vs 1 Champion (boss) monster, and sometimes 2 normal monsters.
Keeper (read: trainer) battles: players will fight with their full party of 6 monsters against a Keeper's party of 6 monsters. Turns are still 3v3, but once a monster is knocked out, their spot is immediately filled with one of the other remaining benched monsters until one side defeats all 6 of the other's monsters.

[b]The Combo System and What Makes Combat Unique? [/b]
In addition to taking advantage of elemental weaknesses and resistances in the rock/paper/scissors fashion that is seen in Pokemon games, MS has a combo system that is integral to use in order to master the game. Each action a monster takes will increase the party's "combo" counter up for the remainder of the 3-monster's turn. If a monster has an attack that hits all three enemy monsters 3 times each, that is a 9-hit combo. The higher the combo meter, the more damage all subsequent monsters will do on their turn. This means a wise strategy is to have your first 1-2 monsters build up the combo meter with multi-hitting buff/debuff/heal abilities to get the combo meter as high as possible, so your final monster in the turn can deal a devastating attack to the enemy team. In the early game you can get by just fine without understanding this mechanic. However, in the mid-late game, enemy monster teams will start taking full advantage of the combo system and will wipe your team if you aren't playing efficiently. The game incentives the player 

[h1] The Creatures, Collecting Them, & Exploring the World [/h1]
There are a bit over 100 creatures in this game, which is smaller roster compared to most Pokemon or other creature collecting games that I have played. However, what this game lacks in quantity, it makes up for with utility. Every creature in MS is unique and therefore useful in its own way. There is no concept of a monster being inherently "inferior" to another monster. Even the evolved versus unevolved forms of monsters each have their own niche. When a monster is evolved, it usually changes its role in some way (such as going from a magic-type attacker to a physical-type attacker) instead of simply just being a "better version" of the unevolved form. In this way, you can have a party with the evolved and unevolved versions of a monster and be effective as they both have their own unique roles to play. 

In addition to their battle skills, each creature will have an "exploration" ability that can be used in the overworld in order to explore and traverse the world in order to access new areas.

[b] The Creatures, Leveling Up, and their Abilities [/b]
Each creature has its own unique set of skill trees to progress through. Every level up will provide a new skill point to obtain a new ability or upgrade an existing one. A monster's level DOES NOT affect its stats, such as its HP, attack, defense, etc. - only how many skill points it has. It is up to the player to decide if they want to use the skill point to increase the base stats or not. Each monster typically has 3-4 individual skill trees to choose from, but you are free to mix and match skill points throughout all of them. The game encourages you to experiment with your options as items to reset spent skill points are plentiful and can be purchased cheaply from the shop. Skills range from active skills (usually consisting of an attack, buff, debuff, shield, or heal) to passive skills. All monsters in the players 6-player party will gain equal experience and will all essentially level up at the same time. This way the player is free to swap in and out their "back row" monsters without fear of them being underleveled due to not experiencing combat.

[b] Collecting Creatures [/b]
Instead of using an item like a Pokeball to capture monsters, new monster are primarily gained in the form of a monster egg at the end of a battle with the monster of that type. The higher star-rating/score the player gets in battle, the higher chance the egg will drop. All wild monsters can be seen in the overworld, so this makes it very easy to find the specific monster you are looking for instead of wandering around aimlessly hoping to randomly find the missing monster your are looking for to complete your collection. Some monsters can only be gained from completing certain quests, getting a 5-star rating from beating Champion monsters, and some can only be gained from evolving a monster.

When hatching a monster from its egg, it will automatically be about 2 levels behind your main party's average level. So if your party consists of six level 20 monsters, new monster eggs will hatch as a level 18 monster. There is a common item in the game that can be found and bought that will increase a monster's level by 1 (up to a maximum of 1 level lower than your highest level monster). This way you can get a new monster, use one of those items, and have a monster that you can safely swap into your main party to try out if you are struggling with a hard fight. This makes it very convenient to experiment with different combinations of monsters without having to waste tons of times grinding levels on bringing a low level monster to the same level as your "main party."

Another great feature with creature collecting in this game compared to Pokemon, is that your have access to every single monster you have hatched at any given time without having to go to a specific storage location to access "stored" monsters. This means you can swap monsters in and out of your party at any time without having to "run back to town" if you happen to run into a boss whose typing is your party's Achilles' Heel. This is a fantastic quality of life feature that is a huge time saver.

143214554.review:
quick note: my playtime is inaccurate, add +20 hours to the time of review. I mostly played and beat the game over one weekend I didn't have internet, so it didn't sync playtime. 

A complex, party-based RPG with a pokemon-like coat of paint and metroidvania world gameplay. Each 'monster' has an extensive skill tree and the name of the game is building synergies with your team. Every action affects your whole team in some way, leading to lots of emergent complexity and synergy. Instead of 1v1 being the standard, battles are 3v3 opening much more possibility for teamplay. But, skill tree resets are very easy to get your hands on, so you don't need to be afraid of investing a dud skill point or going down the wrong path - you can reset and try different things as the monsters unlock new skills, and you rotate in new picks for your team. You can re-skill your entire team after a boss battle to take advantage of a different approach. For me, the real fun in the game comes from optimizing my team so I can beat most battles in 2-3 turns. When wild encounters start lasting more then 3 turns, I know my team isn't keeping up and I need to optimize their skills and equipment. On the other hand, Trainer and Boss battles provide a longer form battle where synergies really shine. Spending 3 turns of set-up and defense to allow your Sweeper to spend the next turn bulldozing an entire team is incredibly satisfying, or setting up a stall + dots team and watching the enemy slowly dots themselves to death.  

The great thing is that wild, trainer, and boss battles are all so emergent different. Wild battles, you get the most rewards for beating them fast so you want some good all-out attack to do these quickly.  Bosses are typically incredibly strong but fairly narrow in scope, so you need to build a counter that really focuses on their strengths and weakness in particular.  20% damage reduction against all kinds of damage won't do you much help on a boss buffed itself to 500% fire damage, so you really need to prepare for exactly what you're fighting, after a few failed attacks to scout out their moveset and weaknesses.  Keeper duels are different again, with a 6v6 style that are highly varied where the Keepers have all the same mechanics and options that you do. All these kinds of battles require different approaches so you never get stuck in a routine and are constantly on your toes, thinking about how you can leverage the skills and abilities to you have to build a plan against the enemy infront of you. 

It is difficult to stress just how important team synergy is in this game. You can't just build each monster individually to fit a predefined role, their role will change fluidly depending on the match-up of allies and enemies. My tank in one battle is my DPS in another is my support in another. All monsters can, and should, do all depending on the situation.  Trying to play most monsters 1-1 matching a role or ignoring synergies with allies (and against enemies) will lead to severe under-performance (and long battles), but the game is very forgiving and you have easy access to re-skills to fix things or just try something new.

Built in new game+ and options for randomized and nuzlocke-style  ('Brave') runs with or without permadeath give this lots of replayability that I'll be sure to keep coming back to.

Gameplay consists of platforming around the place in a metroidvania style environment, and doing pokemon style JRPG-esque battles... it's deeper than most platformers, like, going up to your ankles instead of just the soles of your feet, I suppose. 

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

A choice was made to use obsolete, decades old retro pixel "art" as a substitute for contemporary PC graphics.  It's unclear if this is due to lack of budget or talent, regardless, the overall visual quality of the game is extremely low as a result.

While there are options to change the resolution for the game, all this does is scale up the simplistic 2D art assets used to make the game, which makes little or no difference to the graphics quality.  Without any other substantial graphics tweaks, it's not possible for gamers to improve the lacklustre 2D visuals.

PC gamers will be insulted by the insistence from the developer that a console peasant children's toy controller should be used, despite this being on PC.  Developers should try to be aware which platform they're developing for, and must never, under any circumstances dictate to gamers how their games are to be best experienced.

Compromises were made to cater to the inferior console gaming appliances that the game was designed for.  These are unfortunate compromises and limitations that PC gamers shouldn't be forced to accept, but it's evident that PC was a second thought for the console-centric developers.  The game is deficient as a result of these choices, and would have been so much better without the handicaps that designing games for consoles forces upon a game. These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

I'm 6 hours in and I'm actually legit amazed at this. I wouldn't have thought to cram metroidvania and monster rpg in the same game, but it's absolutely brilliant. The lore is really fun and well-crafted, the game controls super well in the platforming, the graphics are just adorable, and the battle system is just a gem of a thing.

 I can't overstate how much I'm loving the battles- It's a very unique system that's hard to explain but easy to understand by picking up.

For anyone on the fence, I'll try to give as good an explanation as possible:
You get 3 monsters on each side of the battle, and order of operations is really the name of the game, since you can use any of your monsters in any order on your turn. The ultimate goal is to rack up combo points by doing similar actions- attack, debuff, heal, etc- that raises your damage gauge. So, doing two buff actions, then an attack will lead to a much stronger attack than buff-attack-buff. Each option even has a number of times it hits, so you have to weigh going for the bigger number or doing a weaker attack with more hits to rank up that combo meter and then go for a finisher. The buff/debuff system is very robust, as well. All this means that, even though there is an elemental system you will need to engage with, it isn't a mere rock-paper-scissors affair. You can beat monsters with a monster that is technically weak to its element, but has other skills that compensate. 

I will warn you, though- Monster Sanctuary [i]is[/i] a monster collector, but it [i]is not[/i] Pokemon. This game is its own beast, and has its own feel/balance. I actually got my ass kicked by the lil nerd guy the first time I faced off with him! It pissed me off, until I realized "Wait, I just got beat in a [i]monster[/i] game! I never get beat! A fun and solid game that's brought down by a small number of issues.
The game progression (as of writing this review) feels very formulaic as you enter a new biome, catch all monsters, defeat the boss, go to next area. I am currently in the fifth or sixth biome and have uncovered half the map. 

Due to monster variety, and their exploration skills, comes dyslexia as you wander around the world while carrying several pokeboxes worth of monsters with you (while in Pokemon you would find those boxes in the Pokecenter). This freedom is welcome as you always have all skills with you but you slowly realize that it makes menuing needlessly complex. There are options to leave monster behind or at day care but the UI is visible straining because on that screen you do not know which monster has which skills so you go back and forth from main menu to day care deposit. Overworld battles are dmg over everything and you are motivated into doing the monotonous skill rotation combo until the enemies are defeated. For bosses however, you are punished for not building defensively. So either you have specific boss-only monsters that are permanently benched while on overworld, or you build some weird mix-builds which makes the overworld monsters needlessly hard. 

Exploration is nice and the metroidvania effect is wonderfully settled in but the platforming is made by platforming experts (sometimes we need pixelperfect jumps and hover application for those chests), and the switch puzzles are merciless and not fun. The minimap needs some more QoL like the ability to place markers. It's hard to keep track if a maptile is fully explored or waiting for a specific monster's exploration ability. 

Lastly, if your monster is not part of the 6-unit team, they do not earn exp. But only 3 of them are constantly fighting while the other 3 are benched, that's why it's uncommon to really care for equipment for inactive monsters outside of squad battles (6v6, very rare occurence). It becomes apparent that from the vast roster of available monsters, you never actually have a need to switch and just try them out. They need to be skill levelled and they also require equipment, and if you split your exp on too many units, you will be forced to grind to make up for it. Remember specific pokemon from the first generations, the one that you only carry around because they learned HMs? Monster Sanctuary embraced this mindset.

In the end, this game feels nice to play and there is always a small excitement of getting new eggs, checking their skill trees and also their exploration skill. Although transparency in regard to monster roster is not well thought out, this game is definitely worth it if you ever see it on discount.

[h1] A Hidden Gem [/h1]

I'll start this review by saying, not very often I find myself so completely engrossed by a game that I feel that sense of "I really wanna explore everything", but Monster Sanctuary was that and so much more.

As soon as the pixel art style welcomed me into its world, I was captivated. The marriage of 2D platforming and monster-taming RPG elements was not something I expected to blend so seamlessly. However, Monster Sanctuary exceeded my expectations and went above and beyond, offering a beautifully nostalgic experience that was simultaneously fresh and innovative.

One of the strengths of Monster Sanctuary lies in its monster-taming aspect. The variety of creatures available to collect and evolve was astounding and sparked the same joy I experienced in my early days of gaming with titles such as Pokémon. There was an astonishing level of depth in the strategic possibilities for your team, allowing for a real sense of personal attachment to your monsters. The synergy between different creatures and the variety of team combinations provided me with many different experimentations.

The combat mechanics were engaging and satisfyingly tactical. Each battle was a delightful blend of strategy and power management, and I found myself thoroughly engaged mastering the various mechanics. Every victory felt earned, and each defeat was a lesson pushing me to tweak my strategy or grind to boost my team's level.

The Skill Trees for each monster were one of my favorite aspects. It allowed for so much customization and gave a real sense of progression and development for my monsters. Notably, the ability to tailor each creature's skill set to my specific strategies added another layer of depth, granting me a personal connection with my squad that few games offer.

The Metroidvania style exploration was another surprising element that Monster Sanctuary expertly weaved into its gameplay. Each area was filled with secrets, puzzles, and hidden pathways that often required specific monster abilities to access. This gave a reason to not only diversify my monster team for battles but also for navigation and exploration purposes. I spent hours exploring every nook and cranny of this world, my curiosity well-rewarded with unique monsters and valuable loot.

As for the story, it was a pleasantly engaging narrative that served as a fitting backdrop for the game's core mechanics. It was filled with ok characters and nteresting mysteries that kept me pushing forward. It wasn't the most innovative narrative, but it was heartfelt and served its purpose in driving the exploration and battles.

The art and music deserve special mentions. The retro-inspired pixel art is absolutely gorgeous, boasting unique, detailed designs for each monster and an array of vividly created environments. The soundtrack, a beautiful symphony of chiptunes, complements the atmosphere perfectly, further immersing me in the game world.

Monster Sanctuary also has a few minor shortcomings. The pacing could be a bit off at times, with certain areas feeling somewhat dragged out and others seemingly rushed. Moreover, while the monster taming aspect was generally well implemented, the RNG-based nature of monster drops could occasionally feel frustrating. However, these are but minor blemishes in an otherwise masterfully crafted experience.

Completing Monster Sanctuary 100% was not just a testament to its pull but also a testament to its depth. I found myself completely surprised by how much the game offered in terms of content, and how much I enjoyed every single bit of it.

In conclusion, Monster Sanctuary was an unexpected gem that thoroughly impressed me. Its delightful blend of monster-taming, strategic combat, and platform exploration makes it a must-play for any RPG or Metroidvania fans, or for anyone looking for a deep and engaging gaming experience. It's a testament to the adage of not judging a book by its cover, or in this case, a game by its genre-mixing premise. It's not just a game; it's an experience that will take you back to the roots of gaming while also offering something new and innovative. Don't miss out on this one.

It looks a little bit generic, but scratch that surface and there is a LOT of meat underneath.

Monster Sanctuary is a pokemonlike, but it experiments with that formula in a few pleasing ways. The individual mons are less charming and there's less of them than in pokemon, but in exchange each one has a detailed upgrade tree, several possible builds, a light shift and a dark shift, one of three ultimate attacks, and you field them in 3 v 3 battles, making the meta less about switching and more about designing your team so that they can cover each other.

This is a *very* numbers-y game, and it can feel a little grindy for the first half hour, but once you get a few build points into each of your mons it opens up a lot. By mid game, you'll have critters that can drop a moderate damage AoE that also inflicts every debuff and also strips buffs from opponents---and this won't be broken, the game is designed around the player being able to make really busted squads.

In terms of traversal, this *is* technically a metroidvania, since you platform around and look for ways to progress through the map, but there's no real penalty to falling off a ledge or landing on spikes, and most of the progress is gated around monster abilities. Even if you don't have a monster on your team, you can use its traversal abilities at any time.

The plot isn't anything too special, but it has a little bit more stakes than the average monster catcher, and there's a broader universe that gets implied. Music-wise, nothing stood out as jaw-droppingly gorgeous, but all of the tracks were really nice. There's some motifs that sound like they could be at home in Parasite Eve or Chrono Trigger, even if they don't command your attention the way those games' themes do.

Overall, this is a 30+ hour game with fun battles and some really clever design. Don't sleep on it like I did. If you like Number Go Up style rpg gameplay, it's a gem.

Overall very good in all respects. Combat moves quickly and is quite fun, but gains significant depth later on. It offers a lot of choices for building both individual monsters and your party as a whole (and of course, lots of monsters to choose from). Combat rewards are scaled to a ranking of "how well" you fought using a fairly deep but well-explained formula. This serves two purposes very well--it ensures that even in easy fights you're still fully engaged to try to get that ranking, and it provides an extra challenge for boss fights.

By far the best creature collector game out there.  So many unique and cool team compositions and the game makes it super easy to swap out mons to try out different strategies.  

I see a lot of complaints surrounding difficulty but I think that's because people are too used to other games where you're trying to invest in a particular mon. For example: I played a lot of the game with a burn comp.  All my monsters were capable of applying burn.  One of them increased the damage of burns and would gain a shield whenever you did burn damage, another increased how many burn stacks an enemy can have and then the third would make it so burns can cleanse enemy buffs.  None of which are that strong on their own but what you end up with is: stacking burn that ticks 5 times each turn and each tick gives your team a shield, does a ton of damage and vaporizes enemy buffs.

As long as you're thinking about team synergy, you'll have a challenging (but not overly difficult) experience.  It's also super rewarding to put together a team and watch it perform well.  There are no bad mons and all 100+ can be part of a great team if you just find the right combination.

tl;dr: DON'T TREAT THE STORY LIKE A MAINILINE POKEMON GAME. Play this game with the mindset and expectation for teambuilding as you would a deckbuilder or a TTRPG. 
The game can get extremely unforgiving if you don't strategize like that. 

tl;dr P.S. Pay more attention to passive skills than active skills. Talk to your familiar from the main menu if you need some tips on teambuilding.  

~
Whew! Without a doubt, I can say this is probably one of my favorite games of all time, and can wax poetic about its intricate teambuilding and all the fun I've had putting together teams and just running around seeing if they would click. As a result, I will gladly, GLADLY recommend this for anyone who have a blast with intricate turn-based gameplay.

With that being said, for anyone interested in this game for being a Monster Tamer: IT IS NOT EASY, especially compared to something like Pokemon. Considering that series's overwhelming presence over the monster tamer genre as a whole, I've seen several people assume that it's going to be like Pokemon, where you really only need to constantly hit the opponent's weaknesses to win during the story, and subsequently get roadblocked or otherwise struggle. 

Now, the game tries its best to accommodate you while you go about playing. The difficulty curve tries to ease you into the synergies you'll be expected to use by putting them in certain level brackets. As a result, reading the skills of the monsters you're using every 10 levels will help you figure things out, and also clue you in to when things will be getting more difficult.

But, while things will steadily get tougher, the story and general progression doesn't do a great job of actually directing you towards building synergies, and up to a certain point will be fairly brute-force-able. 

That certain point, I would guess, is the cause for most of the negative Steam reviews. It is a very sudden difficulty spike relative to the rest of the story, and while you *could* get into other fights that are just as challenging, if not moreso, those are all in optional sidequests.

The platforming is, admittedly, more on-the-side than a true focus of the game, but is still a considerable part of it. For anyone interested mainly for the fine-tuned tactical gameplay, please keep that in mind.


With all said and done, the tactical depth is impressive even without diving into the PvP scene, the soundtrack and spritework is lovely, and the difficulty lies purely in mastery of the systems in the game itself. If the things I listed interests you in any way, give the game a try!

138555234.review:
Although a monster catching game, Monster Sanctuary is far from the likes of Pokemon. This game is a mix of platforming, monster collecting and metroidvania like exploration. The metroidvania element is mixed with your monster collecting. Progression is tied behind finding and discovering your own abilities or hatching and raising a monster with the ability you need to progress.

Battles in this game are all 3v3. The combat system in itself has a wide breadth of monsters to choose from including vast amounts of equipment and choices in each monsters skill tree.
You are encouraged to build a 'combo' meter during battle not just to do more damage but to get a higher battle rating at the end. This increases the rewards, makes it more likely you get rarer rewards and also increases the chance you can get an egg of one of the creatures you fought!

Going into this game I did not expect the amount of strategy that could be involved in the system nor the difficulty that would come around from being under prepared for certain bosses.
Do not underestimate the necessity of tank or support skills/monsters in this game. They are an absolute must.
Monster sanctuary also takes the idea of form shifts and evolution and does not make them straight up 'better'. Each form or evolution changes a monster to be used differently. Maybe that tank creatures evolution is now completely offence? You are fit to do as you see fit and shape the team you'd like.

Story itself isn't that much but it is serviceable and the strengths of the depth of combat, exploration, soundtrack and art is what shines.

Pros
[list]
[*]Monster sanctuary has lovely QOL. This includes battle speed increase, hatching new monsters are around the level of your highest creature and access to badges to level them quickly. This lets you experiment with new creatures without having to grind too much.
[*]All combat encounters are on map and can be easily avoided and fought. This means you can see what monsters you would fight in 3v3 and pick your battles as and when.
[*]You can re-fight boss battles later to get a higher battle rating and get the egg of the boss/rare materials you may not have gotten the first time.
[*]Large variety of skill trees and strategies including equipment. Lots of potential synergy and variety of things to play with. You can reset skill trees with an item too.
[*]Basically all monsters can be late game monsters. You need to get a good synergy going.
[*]Nice art style and soundtrack that is appropriate for the game. Animations for the monsters is nice and some of the designs of the monsters are creative.
[*]You can hand in any extra eggs and monsters you no longer want to the monster sanctuary to 'increase their army' and gain rewards for your unwanted monsties.
[/list]
Cons
[list]
[*]Most puzzles revolve around levers. Either pull all levers in time or pull levers in the correct order to open doors.
[*]Difficulty sometimes spikes or gets tough unless you have the right counter to a boss. Sometimes some bosses are easily defeated.
[*]Endgame is incredibly difficulty and you need the perfect strategies near enough.
[*]Story is serviceable. You are a monster tamer from a bloodline with a special monster familiar. You are protecting the monster sanctuary. Strong monsters have been appearing recently that need to be defeated. There is a threat of 'Alchemists' and you set out to defeat them and the strong monsters that may or may not be linked.

All in all the game is a great take on two genres I never imagined coming together. Absolutely worth the price especially on sale.

With this, you have a huge variety of options and strategies to find new creatures that boast powerful synergies and can execute a variety of strategies to beat down anything that stands in your way. Whether it's through Brute Force, bolstering through Buffs, debilitating your foes via Debuffs and Status Effects, or slow-rolling your way to insurmountable power and laying waste to all in one giga-powerful assault. There's a lot to experiment with and will definitely keep you occupied throughout the games story and beyond.

On the other side, where you are navigating the titular "Monster Sanctuary", the creatures you find and hatch throughout your journey do more than just provide new strength and new tactics to employ, they're also pivotal to your navigation through the world. Each monster you find have their own unique overworld abilities that help you to traverse the terrain to find new frontiers and interact with puzzles to unlock secret areas and treasures. It's a great incentive to try and "catch them all", since you never know which critter will be the one that helps you open up the next chunk of Map because they can overcome that one obstacle barring your path.

The two together create an experience that actively encourages exploration and experimentation, and really engages you into trying out new strategies and new styles of play in the games battle portions, which I personally absolutely loved and was a fantastic driving force into getting me to complete the game 100%.

Asides from that, there's online PVP to enjoy, an Infinite Arena where you fight increasingly stronger foes until you are eventually overwhelmed with rewards to help you through the game, and a New Game+ for added replayability which features a special Challenge Run, as well as a classic Nuzlocke-style challenge, a Randomiser challenge and finally a recently added "Relics of Chaos" mode, which add new items which drastically change up what you can do in battles, allowing for some truly bonkers strategies.

I absolutely 100% recommend this game. It was an absolute blast to play and I'm certain I'll come back to the challenge runs at a later time also.

137925048.review:
I have extremely mixed opinions about this game.

On the one hand, compared to modern Pokemon games, this game is strictly better for adults who want a monster collecting experience but don't want their hand to be held the entire game.

On the other, the difficulty is ungodly high for no discernible reason. I'm not lying when I say that Dark Souls is an easier and more user-friendly experience. I beat Dark Souls in about 30 hours, and it took me about 85 to beat this game on console. This is especially the case in the late-game, but the difficulty haunts the mid-game as well, not so much the early-game. I bought the game again because I have faith the devs can make the game a bit easier in the future and I wanted to support further updates and new releases from the devs. So far, the balance updates have been in the right direction, especially buffing the weaker monsters to the point where they're, like, usable, but the balance is still completely boned. 

To touch on the balance a bit, some types of monster are just strictly better than other types. Wind and Fire are busted early game, become decent mid-game and fall off hard in the end-game. Because of this, the Eagle starter is by far the best option simply because it not only does the most DPR out of all the starters, it gets abilities that give it Charge stacks in the mid-game to make it even stronger. It does fall off when you can get better Wind monsters late-game, but by then you shouldn't be using your starter anyhow. This is tragic because I really wanted to use the Toad, but all it really does is sit and debuff, and there are far better monsters for debuffing. The question of, "Why debuff when you can buff and use shields instead?", never really gets addressed either, making the team composition problem even more pronounced.

Bosses suck. I'm just gonna say it, they need to be completely reworked. They are either too strong, forcing you to go out of your way to get an entirely new team for one encounter, or far too easy for any team to beat. The easy problem is pronounced in the early-game, but by the late-game, every single boss is far too difficult, forcing you to either get lucky with crits to win (thank god you can increase your crit chance with equipment or the game would be basically unplayable) or again forcing you to get an entirely new team. I never felt like I was using the monsters I wanted to use, only what the game wanted me to use for that specific boss. Expect to have ~10 teams throughout the game. The grinding isn't bad, per se, the monsters scale up to around your level and you can use level badges to get your monsters up a good few levels more, but having to get an entirely new team every single boss fight is so draining.

Shifting is a neat idea, unlocking one out of two free perks for your monsters is a cool customization option similar to Mega Evolution or Z-Moves in the obvious source material, but the item that lets you do this is stupidly rare for the majority of the game. Remember how I said you have to have like 10-ish different teams to effectively beat the game? Yeah, you don't get that many items to shift your monsters, not by a long shot. I found myself running Gray Pearl (item that massively boosts stats for monsters that don't shift) in almost every boss fight, not because I made the decision to run that item instead of shifting, but because there simply weren't enough resources to justify shifting a monster I'm only using for one boss and then dropping. Save your Shift Stones or whatever they're called until you need them to win a boss fight, because you can't effectively farm them until very late in the game. 

Why can't I just get the eggs for the monsters I don't already have at the end of the battle and instead have to get a 5-Star battle rating to have a chance at spawning an egg, one that could be for a monster I already own and don't need? If you want the 5-Star rating system to dictate eggs, then have it do so for monsters you've already got so you can farm for the Monster Army. This just adds to the tedium of farming, it's not interesting and it's bad design.

Why do none of the clothing options change dialogue at all?

Why have overworld puzzles at all when they're so surface level as to be just this: Do you have monster with needed ability? If yes -> Reward. If no -> No Reward. Also, why include some puzzles that are so tedious and convoluted as to necessitate a guide in some areas and then include others that are puddle-deep? The hard puzzles aren't even relegated to the end-game. They're in the mid-game too, in places like Sun Palace. 

Why are there no Keeper battles in the overworld besides story-driven ones? Are we to really believe that a society built on taming and battling monsters only battle them against each other in one of the designated trainer battle areas in the main hub or when it's against an evil team? Are we to believe that every Keeper simply trains their monsters against wild monsters? It's super weird to look at a series like Pokemon and go, "You know what, these trainer battles suck. Let's remove them." The lack of trainers in the areas of the game makes the areas feel dead, like nobody is taming monsters like you are and like everybody is just chilling in the Keeper Stronghold while you're out saving the world. This isn't even getting into the extremely weird limit put on the player in Keeper Duels where during the first turn, the player only gets to make a move with two out of their three monsters. You can't use strategies that depend on all three of your monsters at the beginning of a Keeper Duel, making your first turn always an awkward pick of what part of the strategy you want to execute first, leaving you at a massive disadvantage. 

Overall, I think the game has a lot of potential in terms of how good it could be, but it fails in a lot of areas that don't make a lot of sense for it to fail in. I'm giving it a thumbs-down not because I don't recommend it, I do recommend the game to anyone who finds monster collecting games interesting, but because it needs to be improved. Stop adding monsters and areas and game modes to the game when the core game itself needs to be fixed. I don't recommend you pick the game up for $20. Wait until it goes on sale and pick it up. Hopefully they fix it.

Compared to games like Cassette Beasts, it's simply not as good. Compared to games like the modern Pokemon titles, you may find the difficulty refreshing, or you may find it agonizing like I did.

135551561.review:
I love this game. Something about living in harmony alongside magical animals and protecting them from exploitation and extinction at human hands is very cozy and delightful. Kind of a Jane Goodall in a D&D world fantasy.

A mon game mixed with a Metroidvania feels like a chocolate/peanut butter combination. It's perfect together. You can walk around with a monster and command it to use its world power. These can open doors, allow new forms of traversal, or activate puzzle triggers. These new regions reveal new items, mobility tools, and, of course, new mons with new abilities. It can be a little 1-D at times. Why can't my flying magical seahorse help me swim or fly? That's not his power, idk. Occasionally the levels feel very deliberately gated, but that's just a metroid thing.

The combat is much more crunchy, complex, and in-depth than other mon games I've played. It's 3v3 and you have a combo meter that powers up moves later on in your turn, so you often build teams of a tank, a setup, and a hitter monster in different mixes based on what you have and what you are trying to beat, but you can also build a shield-sustain team grinds down enemies, or replace a direct hitter with a congeal, burn, or poison build. My favorite part was figuring out how the mons can work and how those can synergize. I am not a competitive mon battler and I don't recall any main quest fights being hard, but I never skipped a fight, enjoyed 100%-ing the map, and loved learning how all the critters fought, so it felt great to me. Honestly it feels like exactly the kind of strategy game I love, namely, that you get to explore the world and express your love for your favorite parts by making them part of your adventure going forward. And you get to customize them to suit your team.

The ability tocall up any monster at will or hatch eggs to get a monster near your party's level is great, letting you mix up your combat team or try new mobility powers, I only wish they weren't underleveled. Not sure why the game goes 90% of the way to make that mostly seamless to throw up an arbitrary limit like that. Also, getting a specific mon egg can be annoying because a lot of it is based on RNG, like if you hatch a boss monster early, it can easily fall behind and leveling them up can be expensive/tedious. Annoying, but a lot less annoying than finding a trade from another copy of the game anyways.

As for negatives, I wish the lore was more in-depth, but a lot of the lore comes from "fun animal facts" that have little relation to each other, except "humans almost killed off this monster, until they were relocated to the Monster Sanctuary." It reminds me of the Gen 1 Pokedex, where it kind of implies Kanto is just a part of the world where the animals are Pokemon, but never really explores that much. Also, there are so many ways to build each mon that memorizing all of the options can make hi-level fights extremely opaque, even as someone who enjoys a lot of fiddly builds in D&D or Pathfinder.

Reading this back, it feels like a very "mixed" review, but I am just warning about the crunchier parts of this chocolate/peanut butter mix that I think is exceptionally fun. I bought the game for myself on sale and then again full price so my brother could play it.

Monster Sanctuary is a masterpiece of creature collectors. The game has an immense amount of strategy, a diverse set of creatures to collect, and a large world to explore. There is much to love about this game, and I would personally struggle to find any flaws that I have with the game.

The game's strategy has a lot of depth for those looking for it with deep decision-making both in battles and in team-building. In battles, there many systems, such as combos, buffs, and debuffs, all of which need to be considered in the order of the actions. Rather than a single-battle system, Monster Sanctuary has you use three monsters at a time to battle. The synergies between three monsters influence how you think about building your team with each monster having their own builds and things to customize to further add to your strategy. Also, the game is difficult enough that it is important to understand these things; there were many times after losing a fight that I would replace a certain member of my team or change the build of one of my monsters.

The music and visual presentation of the game are also very strong. The music fits very well, either providing energy in fights or providing the ambiance to the numerous areas of the game. The pixel art of the game is visually appealing and detailed, as well as the monster designs are varied and fun. The world and story are solid, providing a good backdrop to the whole adventure.

The biggest flaw I had with the game was the clunky menu. The menu was definitely designed with a controller in mind, and while fine to navigate with keyboard and mouse, there could have been improvements to how the menu is presented. This is especially noticeable near the end of the game, where players would have countless items to manage and look over, and the menu can feel a little of a hassle to traverse.

Overall, I quite enjoyed the game, even going out of the way to 100% it. For anyone who enjoys games like Pokemon, this game is an easy recommendation. During a sale, this game has a ridiculous amount of value. I am very much looking forward to this studio's next game that they are coming out with.

Monster Sanctuary is a fantastic game. It's not a Pokemon clone, and if you go in expecting that you're going to be disappointed. You should think of this game more like a standard JRPG with a huge roster of playable characters and extremely high customization.

Pros:
- Game's difficulty is naturally dynamic. If you take your time and progress slowly you'll level enough that there won't be too much challenge, but if you move at a brisk pace you'll find a decent challenge awaiting you.
- Customization options are through the roof and respec items are readily available. Build your team exactly how you want it.
- Exploration is fun and rewarding. Your monster talents help you progress, but are typically not mandatory. This rewards you for having a big collection without punishing you if you don't.
- Platforming is precise and feels good. Mobility options through some monsters let you customize how you get around.

Cons:
- Combat system might be intimidating to first time casual players. Stick with it and talk to NPCs and you'll figure it out eventually. Levelling and equipping items will help if you're stuck.
- If you're the "get all the monsters" type of player you may find yourself over-leveling the game's challenge. My suggestion is to rotate out your party often if you're taking your time and you want to avoid the game becoming too easy.

I have mixed feelings. I was having a blast for my first 30 hours in Monster Sanctuary. I was enjoying it so much I couldn't wait to finish so I could begin my second playthrough. Later areas of the game went in a different direction and it completely killed my enthusiasm for the game. There is a difficulty spike towards the end that is absolutely ridiculous, and I don't think I'll ever replay this as a consequence. I am giving this a positive review because of how much I enjoyed the first half of the game, but this was a very tough call for me. The difficulty spike really soured how I feel about the game. I've seen this game described as Pokemon for adults, and I think that is a fair assessment.

There are a lot of nicely polished elements. I much appreciated that new monsters were close in level to my current party, and there are level-up badges that can be acquired. I especially liked that max-level monsters continue to gain EXP to grant me more of the level-up badges. The pixel art is fantastic, most of the music is good, exploring is very satisfying. Nearly every monster is useful and viable in some way - I wouldn't say any of them are junk. Some are kind of niche though. I was surprised that only a handful of monsters can change form, but overall there was a satisfying amount of monster variety. Replayability seems good because of NG+ and the monster randomizer setting.

I don't ordinarily play metroidvania titles because I'm not a fan of precision platforming nor trying to remember all the dozens of places I need to backtrack to. The ability to add markers to the map was a welcome addition to dealing with finding  things, but unfortunately there was just enough difficult platforming to irritate me.

The concept of using the monsters for navigation, their vast array of abilities, synergies, etc., is all fantastic. I enjoyed studying the abilities and strategizing about what combos to use. I also enjoyed the exploration aspect of the game. The pacing of the exploration fell a bit flat though. For example, I got the first flying ability very early in the game, then the improved version about halfway through. I got the basic swimming ability and replaced it with the improved version less than an hour later. Nearly all navigating can be accomplished with double jump, and occasionally an area specific ability like swimming. Monster explore abilities are mostly confined to locking out new areas and hiding treasure. The only place that really used the monster abilities for lots of navigation was the Forgotten World at the endgame. Some abilities like Grapple were really underused, and almost exclusively used for finding treasure. It would have been better if various monster abilities were needed to explore more in previous areas aside from just getting a couple of treasure chests.

I am absolutely not a fan of the 5-star combat rating system and how it is used to calculate loot rewards. That is the kind of trash I'd expect to see in a mobile game. There is too often nothing you can do to earn 5 stars besides dumb luck or being vastly over the level of the things you're fighting. I am super-duper not a fan of having to 5-star all of the bosses and having their level scale to mine. That kind of grindy crap is super tedious to me, as well as the [spoiler] lategame area with the keeper statues to battle.[/spoiler]

Combat gets progressively more complicated as your monsters level up and gain new abilities. Keeping track of things after midgame and figuring out what works well is very challenging. I also never quite figured out why some monsters do so much more damage than others. Say I could have 2 different monsters, both with similar attack/magic stats, similar crit chance/damage, etc. Acting 3rd in combat gives the highest bonus damage, so I'd expect either monster to be able to fill that role equally, but somehow, some monsters just don't do the damage that others do even with the same stats. I used a Ninki Nanka for a while and his attacks were less than half the damage from my spectral familiar even with same stats, for example.

After level 25 or 30 I noticed the combat difficulty starting to climb. By level 40 I was extremely frustrated with combat. My monsters had 4-6k hp, could hit for 1-2k damage, and had all level 5 upgraded gear. Enemy monsters had 10-12k hp and could hit for 4k+. It seems the enemy monsters don't have equipment, so their stats are boosted to make up for it but it is way too much. I absolutely hate when enemies don't play by the same rules that I am constrained by. I also hated keeper battles because I always start with a disadvantage: Only 2 of my 3 monsters can act the first round, but the enemy gets the usual 3 actions. Some endgame battles were profoundly stupid - enemy with 55% dodge rate and 5 stacks of regeneration healing for 22.5% of their hp every round, with more automatic healing when they attack and automatic debuff cures on top of all that! Doesn't help to try knocking off their buffs either because they automatically come back. Unbelievably frustrating. I also didn't like anything to do with the entier Keeper's Tower area - all that crap felt like themepark challengines from a mobile game.

I realize this is a lot of complaining for a positive review, but keep in mind it is an extremely narrow positive.

133271286.review:
[b][u]This game was reviewed using Version 2.0.0.55. Your experience on other versions may vary.[/u][/b]

[h3][b][u]Short Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] An engaging turn-based battler and creature collector, with a bit of metroidvania influence in its level design. The 3v3 battles and unique combo system add a lot of strategy to each encounter, and it's designed so that every monster can shine with the right team. Some late-game difficulty spikes can lead to frustration, but there are community guides to help you get the most power out of your team if you need it. Way more fun than I expected, and the only reason I stopped at 40 hours is because I ran out of things to do.

[b][u]NOTE[/u]: Slight [u]epilepsy warning[/u] due to many attacks including screen flash effects--not very strong or rapid effects, but I'm throwing out a warning to be on the safe side.[/b]

[h3][b][u]Long Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] [i]Monster Sanctuary[/i] is a turn-based creature collector game that has you playing as a Monster Keeper, someone capable of hatching, training, and fighting alongside monsters that roam the land known as the Sanctuary. As you work to rise up in the ranks in hopes of becoming a Keeper Master, you stumble upon a secret organization that seeks to overthrow the Keepers and upset the delicate balance between humans and monsters; and it's up to you to put a stop to them. I almost skipped over this one purely because I generally dislike turn-based combat in games these days; but I'm glad I decided not to, because it ended up way more fun than I would've expected.

The core gameplay loop is pretty simple: you fight monsters in turn-based combat, collect eggs from these battles to hatch a copy of the species you got it from, then use them to build a 6-monster team that works best for you. My knee-jerk reaction is to compare it to the likes of Pokémon, but that comparison alone doesn't give you a good sense of all the things it does to set itself apart:
[list]
[*]Instead of awarding specific abilities at specific levels, [b]every monster has JRPG-style skill trees unique to them that let you choose what you earn each level[/b]. These skill trees are diverse enough that you have the freedom to build each monster one of several ways--single-target vs multi-target damage, buffing allies vs debuffing opponents, X elemental vs Y elemental, etc.--and nearly all of the game's strategic elements stem from figuring out what setup work best with your current team composition. This can be tough to wrap your head around at first, and you will end up picking things that turn out to be unhelpful; but you're encouraged to experiment, so they make it easy to reset a monster's skills should you find that your current build isn't working out for you.

[*][b]Battles are all 3v3, so there's a lot of emphasis on making sure your team has good synergy with one another[/b]. This can either mean a team where each monster fills a different core role (healer/defense, buffs/debuffs, damage dealer), or a team where one monster's skills directly compliment another (e.g. one triggers a bunch of debuffs, another gets a damage boost for each debuff an enemy has).

[*][b]There's this interesting combo system where every successful hit on an enemy adds a damage multiplier to your next monster's attack that turn[/b]. The idea is to use your weaker multi-hit moves to rack up a high combo, then take full advantage of the damage boost with your heavy-hitter or a move that can exploit the enemy's weakness. It adds another layer of strategy to each turn, but the best part is that non-damaging support skills also add to the combo--sometimes even more than attacking would. This means that even monsters that never attack still indirectly contribute to overall damage output, which means you don't need to compromise by including support monsters on your team--and on a related note,

[*]In many creature collectors, there's a clear progression where your early creatures are meant to either evolve in some fashion or be set aside in favor of stronger late-game creatures. While that can happen here too, it's by no means a requirement--[b]from the first blob you meet to the last boss you defeat, all 111 unique monsters are designed so that they can be viable with the right build and the right team.[/b]
[/list]

A lot of the marketing references a metroidvania influence, and that mainly stems from the overworld map design. You have a 2D side-scrolling map comprised of distinct but interconnected regions, a ton of secrets and shortcuts to uncover, and a lot of backtracking to get to them since they require abilities you don't unlock until later on. You actually get these from the monsters you capture, as each species has an "Explore Ability" that lets them tackle one or more of the obstacles in your way: flight, swimming, breaking hidden walls, activating special switches, and so on. Usually any monster whose ability fits the description will work (e.g. "Activates fire orbs"), but occasionally you'll require a specific monster because their version of said ability behaves just a little different than the rest. With all that said, the genre's influence starts and ends there; so [b]don't buy this expecting a full-fledged metroidvania, because the turn-based combat is the real focus here.[/b]

I've seen some reviews say that the difficulty of the late game put a premature end to their run, and that it conflicts with the game's core philosophy that "every monster can be viable"--and they do have a point. [b]Late-game Keeper battles use tactics that induce a sudden, sharp spike in difficulty; and it can be very tough for most teams to counter them.[/b] I personally didn't have much trouble here, but that's because my go-to team by this point just happened to be a good pick for these fights. If you're having trouble with your current setup, I'd suggest looking at [url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1s7GtJveVZzjxZqGjO4u1_2pM_4k5dVBrW_SVLcJK9j8/]SmugLookingBarrel's recommended monster builds[/url] to see if there's a way to better optimize your current team. I can also recommend the team I used--one that's fairly easy to put together--but that could take away the fun of discovering things on your own, so see if you can beat it with your own team first before reading:
[list]
[*][spoiler]Scattered throughout the game are six different goblins: the first three can be found at the same time (Brute, Hood, Warlock), and the rest are found separately later on (King, Miner, Pilot). Each one has skills that compliment one another very well, including one passive skill (which can be unlocked as soon as you get them) that provides significant buffs to all other goblins in the party. This team--often just the first three, even--along with SLB's builds can get you through every main story battle with ease, and it's also well-suited for most optional and post-game content.[/spoiler]
[/list]
One last piece of advice to address another common complaint: [b]there's an option to speed up battle animations anywhere from 1x to 3x--[u]USE IT[/u][/b]. Start at 1x until you get comfortable with the mechanics and/or fights start to drag, bring it up just a bit, rinse and repeat; don't start with 3x or you're gonna struggle to understand what's going on.

[b]What started as a hesitant 1-hour test run turned into a 40-hour 100% completion run[/b], and it's safe to say that I'm really glad I gave it a chance--and now I'm thinking I should go back and give some more turn-based games I passed on another chance too. [b][u][i]Monster Sanctuary[/i] hooked me way more than I expected it to; and I only wish that I had more of it to play.[/u][/b]
