I could write an essay about this game, but I'll try to keep it short and sweet. I'll put the TLDR in caps and for those who want a more in depth idea as to why I like or dislike something, you can read beyond the caps. Keep in mind that these are just my opinions. My taste in things like artistry and music may be different than yours.

----PRO'S----
-THE SPRITES AND MONSTER JOURNAL ART.   Incredible art and spriting of all the characters. Whilst sprites can rarely do their drawn versions justice, the sprites give the monsters more life than I see in many games these days that use them. When you have a favorite Mon that you think looks so cool, that you're hellbent on making a team around them, you know the sprites are awesome. I sincerely appreciate the Monster Journal as well for giving you a peek at how the monsters actually look as well as some lore about what and who they are, how they came to be, etc., Some look cute, some absolutely cool looking, some somehow both.

-BALANCE.    Whilst you can say that no game will ever manage to 100% balance everything, especially in a game like this where you're putting together a 3 man team, especially especially when they're acting together rather than one or two at a time like in pokemon, the fact remains that they've still done a fantastic job of making sure the vast majority of the monsters feel like they *could* be godly together and give you a power trip, whilst still staying within the games boundaries at the same time. It takes a considerable amount of team crafting (at least alone without looking up guides) to really craft a team that feels broken in any way. I made a team called AFKBleeds that literally just sits there shielding itself, healing, and debuff stripping whilst the enemy bleeds to death for massive bleed and debuff dmg numbers, and I still had a few teams give mine a run for their money.

-AMOUNT OF CONTENT.     This one's not the most remarkable on why I like the game. With the story being somewhat short compared to most game stories, it's carried decently well by the fact that this is a game where you'll be keeping a lookout for and backtracking for loot, hatching and evolving monsters, and overall sitting down and theory crafting the perfect team. If you're here for the long and engrossing story, I've got bad news. If you're here for the amount of hours you'll put in, I welcome you to the Sanctuary my friend.

-REPLAYABILITY.     So, you've beaten the game after killing the Big Bad, whadya do now? Well, that depends. Are you a treasure hoe like me? Get to exploring until you've 100% the map of all its hidden loot. Ya wanna Catch Em All? Go beat the daylights out of every monster until it pops out an egg for you in its deaththroes and 5 star the champions you've beaten for theirs. Ya wanna see if your seemingly unbeatable team truly is unbeatable? Game's got ya covered with the Infinity Arena where you go up against random AI teams that ever increase in lvl, but reward prizes and gives you a highscore. Ya got online pvp to see whose team's the cheesiest. Ya can fight the rest of the games *Super* Champions. You can fight against any number of the more secret easter egg enemies and teams post-game.

MUSIC-   Again, this is my own opinion, and honestly this one is a mix. I did like some of the music. When I play a game with any sort of combat and I/we're about to face up against a powerful opponent, I want something that makes me feel like, "This is it, team. They may be tall, but we've proven we're taller. Steel yourselves and show these dudes how we got here!" They've got some solid tracks in that area. A tiny bit samey after listening to the same ones a number of times, but solid all the same. The music for the overworld fits pretty well too. This world is a Sanctuary. Whilst there is fighting to be had, it's meant to be a place of nature, and the tracks capture that pretty well. I won't pretend to know music instruments and their terms for different strings and such, but the track did well in the immersion department. The only nitpick I could give is that for a combat junkie like myself, the peaceful and nature-esque tracks further agitate my itch for getting back in combat asap.

CUSTOMIZABLE-   Did you already name your character or monster, but you just thought of an even better one? You can change both. Granted, the monster name changer is a little later in the game, but it's there. Are you gender-fluid or just recently realize your real gender? The costume changer allows you to take on the costumes of the other gender, effectively letting you switch genders whenever you visit em.


-----CONS------

STORY-     I don't feel like the story quite deserves to be in the con section, personally, but of all the things that'll wow you in this game, the story-telling here definitely won't be among them. It's a little short without the other content in between, the characters didn't have any real self development arcs other one of em being, "I was a duchecanoe to you earlier, but having the floor mopped with my face one time made me humble," and I usually like for my Big Bad villains behind everything to be more than Bad for the sake of being Bad, but it was passable. To put it in perspective, if I had to give it a grade, the story would be like, "Well lil Timmy, ya didn't fail. I can tell you did the barebones work to pass and that's what ya get. A barely passing grade."

MAP LOOT-   Now, while I understand that some folks aren't teamcrafters and are gonna struggle and need to rely on potions to get em through, it did make me frown a bit every time I discovered a sneaky breakable wall or finally got the right creature to reach a bit of loot, only to find a potion or singular bit of fruit. Honestly, I'd have rather just gotten some straight up gold to spend on food I actually needed or maybe some upgrade ingredients with how hard those burned up my wallet. Also...I think I'd feel a little weird if irl I found a hidden treasure chest with a single half rotten strawberry in it.

THE COSTUME SKINS-    While I found the skins to be well done, I found it a lil uncomfortable the way they were...well actual skins. You'd often have a costume with a myriad of colors to em, which is awesome, but you'd have like 7 or 8 of em being a white person and have like 1 or 2 blacks people. While I may not be black, and I'm not gonna pretend I'm the vanguard of black folks issues, but that just feels weird. I get there's not a character template on top of which the costumes are being placed on, but this doesn't feel like the way to go about being inclusive. It feels shoehorned in and as if you're being restricted to which colors you can wear if you care about your character representing the irl you to a any degree.  I think it would probably have been less weird if instead of having 9 different colors with 1 or 2 being black skinned, if you just had like, say 3 skin colors and then the same 3 costume colors for each skin color. Same amount of spriting work, possibly even less actually if ya think bout it, and a lot less weirdness.

Bout all I can think of for the moment. I'll update if I think of anything else. I hope this helps you decide if you wanna grab it for your library or not.

If you've ever wondered what would happen if you crossed an in-depth creature battler with a charming metroidvania, you now have your answer.

Monster Sanctuary is unique in how it crosses the two genres together. Both compliment each other well; new monsters allow you traverse to new locations which means you can find more monsters etc. Whilst the metroidvania map may not be as in depth as some of the leaders of the genre, there is plenty of secrets and reasons to explore previous locations.
 
The combat in the game is super in-depth and a joy to master. Every creature fits a role and they all have different synergies with one another. For example I had a creature which inflicted high stacks of "frost" on a creature. I then had another creature which speacialised in doing extra damage to enemies based on the amount of "frost" stacks they had on them. I constantly wanted to try out different synergies and the game kept providing unique combos and movesets. There are also additional mechanics you unlock through the game which add even more layers to the combat.

This game does unfortunately have some flaws though, particularly towards the late game. Regular enemies become super tanky and fights begin to drag out. You will have a build which means you won't lose but because the enemies are so tanky it becomes a rinse a repeat until they die.

Overall a unique combination of genres which I thoroughly enjoyed, even if parts in the late game become overly dragged out.

The music slaps too.

One of my favorite games of recent years.  Metroidvania-style exploration, coupled with very nuanced party build dynamics make this a great game, and well worth the buy.

The nuance starts with "Oh hey, using skills with lots of hits with my first two monsters helps my third monster do more damage," moves to "huh, this monster I just got lets me stack multiple Frost debuff stacks on an enemy, and my current one causes damage every round to enemies based on how many frost stacks they have. Hmm...", and finally moves somewhere around building a party around multiple very specific interdependent themes later on.

The monsters are quite varied, and as one might guess there are quite a few secret ones to locate.  That you can even add boss monsters you've faced to your party (assuming you've defeated them with a full five star rating for performance) is a great touch.

This sort of nuance and detail to it make it so if you ask five different people their favorite party setup to go against serious Champion monsters, you'll very likely get five different and equally valid answers.  As you might imagine, this gives the game some fantastic replay value.

[b]TL;DR: strong recommendation for this game. 9/10[/b]
+Pros: Surprising depth and complexity, EXCELLENT ON STEAM DECK
-Cons: Difficulty curve too slow to prepare player for end game

This cross between a Pokemon "catch 'em all" and metroidvania-esque map is far more complex than it seems on the surface. At the beginning of the game, I thought I was in for a rather quick experience (10-15 hours) without too much depth. But as the game unfolded and new areas became available, you find yourself in a well-developed RPG with loads of replayability.

In fact, after you finish the final "story" mission, you will look at your map completion and realize you're missing an entire new area that has not been available until you get skills from monsters you only recently gotten.

If there is one negative I have, it's that the difficulty ramps up too slowly. For most of the game, you can survive without needing to think about synergies and how the buff/debuff system works. As long as you have monsters that can counter your enemies' weaknesses, you can largely succeed up to the very final few "story" fights. However, those last few fights really require a team with more thought about how the buff/debuff systems work and being intentional with the weapons, items, and food you give to your monsters.

I was able to get through the final fight after several hours trying new combinations, but I felt frustrated that many of the strategies that had been so successful failed at the very end. 

One additional side note is that the rarer achievements (especially with the champion fights) really require specific setups. [spoiler]There is a guide of one team that is particularly effective for most post-game fights here in Steam, even though it states it is outdated.[/spoiler] I think if you had a lot of time to play around with different styles of gameplay (and by a lot of time, I mean 50-100+ hours), then it could be a fun puzzle to solve. However, I felt like I had already put in the time I wanted to in this game and opted to seek out the best setups possible to get these final achievements.

Despite these qualms, I really did enjoy playing this game and plan on recommending it personally to several friends I know would enjoy this game.

I bought this one while it was on sale. It was surprisingly entertaining. Take a classic NES Legend of Zelda, throw in some old gen Pokemon and that pretty much describes Monster Sanctuary. 

Story- Very simple, quick fantasy story with interesting lore. Perfect story for speed runs. Emotional moments between characters are rare. Some character development for a select few. Pretty generic RPG characters. Expanding the story would not have hurt however the story presented feels mostly complete. In the end, it feels like there could/should be a MS2 around the corner. The history/lore is a fascinating start for what could be expanded on in many different ways.

Graphics- Great work for the low bit level. And who doesn't love a 2D pixel game. The classic side scrolling style made it feel reminiscent old-school LOZ. While the battles are similar to old gen pokemon battles with more a bit action/movement. The attack graphics are mostly layered color tones dependent on the element of the monster. The monsters themselves are fantastic! They look awesome during battle and one can follow you while you run around the beautiful 2D map. 

Gameplay- Not open an world map. Areas are cut off until certain story requirements are met. Lots of hidden doors/caves cover the map. The map itself could have had a few more sections but the diversity of those sections in the game remind me of Subnautica. The battles are where the real fun is. With a litany of monsters to build teams from, its easy to make several team builds with only 6 monsters. The monsters have individual skilltrees you earn points for as the monster levels up. Some have heaing, some have attack, and some defense based trees with MOST monsters having a mix of all three. Battles are teams of 3X3 and effect each other WAY more than pokemon. Easy interface during battle.

Lots of things I loved about this game.  I personally enjoy RPG strategy games that allow battle monsters to support each other. The cool monsters and the genuinely fun gameplay make it very re-playable. The only complaint is that there should have been more story and an expanded map.

131548910.review:
Pokemon + Metroidvania + skill trees + challenge runs

Core gameplay: 10 - 20 hours (I spent 60 to 70 hours before I "beat" the game, but I explore/collect everything/where). Run around, collect monsters, beat champions/NPCs, unlock new areas, rinse & repeat.

Platforming: Mostly easy, with lots of locked/secret areas. Different monster abilities  required to get 100% chests/secrets/areas
Story: It's a story, simple but functional. I think there is potential for a more story-focused title in this universe, but I feel that this particular game is mainly focused on the mechanics and worldbuilding.
Map exploration: oh god where is the one map tile i haven't found
PvP: Haven't tried it, but likely to get roflstomped by people who built good teams.

Core Mechanics:
Party of 6 monsters, only 3 of which can be out at a time. You pick their skills and items (and can change them). Straightforward and easy to learn, with a crapton of options/builds/setups.
You fight monsters 3 at a time, NPCs 3 at a time with a total of 6, and champion monsters 1 to 3 at a time.
Collect monsters by fighting them and hoping for an egg (open inventory, hatch egg, voila). Or get lucky with rewawrd boxes (random eggs/items).
Monsters provide overworld exploration abilities such as Mount/Fly/Light/Claws/Tackle, etc etc. Some are rarer than others, some direct improvements to others, some hardlock world areas without them (swimming). The more the merrier.

Replayability: Absolutely. You can play with whatever monsters you want, some are weak and some are strong but all are viable to beat the game with. Included challenge modes and difficulty options allow significant challenge. Nuzlocke + random monsters + permadeath are included options, and the hard difficulty is unforgiving without a NG+ save file. Speaking of, NG+ allows to use existing save file, saving items and resetting monsters.

Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this game. I had a lot of fun (and frustration at times) and I hope to see more DLC (last one was included free in base game). 

Cons: There's only around 110 monsters, which isn't a con, I just wish there was more. More everything. Like in a sequel, I would pay full price for a sequel with more world/items/story/monsters/skills/abilities/everything.

I generally had a good time with this game.  The monsters all have fun designs and the fundamental gameplay is pretty engaging (I generally don't enjoy turn based party combat.)  The exploration and team building are also enjoyable and I encountered no bugs or technical issues.  With that said, some fights get annoying or drag on a bit, even with the built in system to prevent that.  Regardless, I certainly got my money's worth out of it and feel comfortable recommending it.

For context, I approached the game (on normal difficulty) by making one generalist team to handle every challenge without using consumables.  This was doable, and I'm glad I didn't have to build separate teams for each champion or keeper duels (essentially two variations of boss battles).  That said, I put a lot of thought into my team's skill trees to have answers for most weaknesses, damage types, and especially debuffs.  I also didn't like keeper duels enough to do the post game duels or several of the side objective duels and I only got 5 star ratings on a handful of champions.  So if you want to do literally everything the game has to offer, your mileage may vary.

Overall fantastic game, buy if you love strategy monster battlers, full price is worth it, a must-buy on sale.

THE CONS: 
1. This is not an easy game. By the end of the game, you cannot have a level advantage; your ability to win depends entirely on your ability to make a team that functions well. 
2. The strongest team composition strategies are chance-based, so get ready to brute force some fights in your lucky slippers with a rabbit's foot in one hand and your lucky Bible in the other.
3.  The metroid-vania aspect of gating through monster abilities is a little tedious and unnecessary. I love the animations but organizing your active monster once you've got an enormous library of monsters is cumbersome. 

THE PROS: 
1. Strong aesthetic style
2. Great music
3. Option to scale all monsters with your level for more challenge
4. Endgame challenges present significant difficulty
5. No limit on monsters in inventory
6. No limit on items; you can farm as many as you want of every item with enough patience/knowledge
7. Exceptionally deep and versatile skill system (I spent a couple hours learning skill trees to build teams)
8. 101 monster types, a few evolutions but each "unevolved" form is potentially just as viable. Every monster is a viable member of a strong team. 
9. New game+ options
10. Various costumes
11. ~50 hours to complete all achievements

THE MEDIOCRE: 
1. Story isn't anything impressive, but still better than pokemon. 
2. Game at max speed is fine, could be better with a faster option. 

Again, very charming game, made with a ton of love. Well worth your time if you love pokemon.

129579535.review:
If you got this expecting a regular RPG where you can just grind for levels and then mindlessly spam 1 button to defeat everything, this will not meet that expectation.

Monster Sanctuary is a game about strategy and synergy. Each monster has their own skill tree and with a fairly common item, you can reset it at any time to find the most optimal build. There are 6 monsters in your active team but you have an unlimited (dynamically changing) inventory of monsters with you at all times so you can swap to any team outside of battle whenever you please. This is made even better with the ability to save and load teams. And if you thought the game couldn't add more complexity for team building, later on you have the ability to "shift" light/dark alignments, and each one gives your monster a different ability and stats. So yeah, there is a lot to this game.

I just finished the game + the free DLC, and I love this game enough that I've been writing team synergies on an excel sheet. If you love monster capturing games, then this is definitely for you. The artwork is also great. I love the detailing on each monster, each with their own ability you can use in the overworld.

Story-wise, I would say it's kinda mediocre, however, gameplay-wise there is a lot of content and many secrets that are not part of the story to discover. I've had to run back to places I've been to before because I obviously missed something and I need to figure out how to get from Point A to Point B.

Another thing to keep in mind is that the enemies will scale with you as you progress through the game (and there's also an option to keep EVERY enemy scaled and not just the new ones you encounter) because any enemies in any new map tile you explore, will be around or at the level of your strongest monster, which just reinforces the idea that you need to really strategize and not just mindless mash A. If you find yourself repeatedly dying from enemies or bosses, regroup and redo your skill trees - buffs and debuffs go a long way.

Additionally (because of course there's even more), New Games have new modes now for even more challenges. There's even a permadeath mode which I feel would be great for pokemon nuzlocke players lol

Anyway, highly recommend this game. Clearly a lot of passion went into it and it shows.

Aún no me lo he pasado pero creo haber entendido suficiente del juego y quisiera comentar lo que pienso, creo que podría ayudar a algunos a decidir sobre si comprarlo o no. Si mi opinión cambiara, más adelante actualizaré la crítica, pero dudo que suceda.

Este juego es una interesante combinación de géneros. Es un plataformas en 2d donde distintas áreas pueden desbloquearse conforme progresas y quedan para siempre abiertas para que las visites en algo que se parece un poco a un mundo abierto (en realidad no lo es, vas desbloqueándolo luego no es abierto). El sistema de combate consiste en un rpg por turnos engañosamente sencillo, en realidad tiene bastante profundidad jugable. Básicamente vas por el mundo derrotando monstruos para conseguir sus huevos, con los que obtienes inmediatamente crías de dichos monstruos y puedes reclutarlos para formar equipos de 6 que luchan en combates de 3 vs 3. 

Si has jugado pokémon pero lo encuentras excesivamente simple, esto es justo lo que necesitas. No es tan simple como plantar un monstruo de un tipo que te de ventaja, ya que casi siempre implica también vulnerabilidades. Y el rol de los bufos y debufos es clave y otorga un dinamismo estratégico al juego que encuentro genial. Los monstruos están preparados para cumplir los roles fundamentales como tanque, o sweeper, con multitud de habilidades especiales, técnicas y recursos. No aprenden una lista de ataques (que también), también adquieren habilidades pasivas, tienen árboles de skills para ello, y hasta puedes equiparles armas y accesorios.

Los monstruos también pueden evolucionar, pero no os explico cómo. Ya lo descubriréis, es curioso.

Tiene toda la pinta de que los desarrolladores de este juego, igual que muchos de nosotros, no entendían la reticencia de Nintendo a desplegar todas las posibilidades del concepto base de pokémon, y con un presupuesto pequeño y un poco de pixel art, han logrado más que Gamefreak en los últimos 10 años. El gameplay es más interesante, adictivo y desafiante, el lore es llamativo y lo más importante de todo, EXISTENTE. Y tiene modo pvp, aunque aún no lo he probado.

A ver, seamos realistas. Dado el presupuesto, esto es un pequeño juego indie. No tendrá tantos monstruos como pokémon ni de lejos, seguramente gente con poca experiencia escribiendo habrá terminado de redactar una historia que olerá a fanfic por todos lados y probablemente podríamos hablar todo el día de todo lo que se puede mejorar.

Pero esto lo compráis por 5 o 10 euros (yo lo cogí por 2 euros) y con pokémon tenéis que pagar 50 o 60 euros por productos inacabados e incompletos de una compañía que detesta a cada uno de sus jugadores y que seguramente escupa en cada cartucho que venden (y sólo voy medio en broma). 

Así que... Sí. Recomiendo bastante Monster Sanctuary. 

[h1] Un pequeño rpg 2d por turnos con tintes de metroidvania que mejora la fórmula de pokémon en los aspectos más fundamentales y crea algo con personalidad propia. Precio ideal: 12 euros o menos, pero en ofertas se puede encontrar muy barato. [/h1]

[/spoiler]

Game play (8.5)
-.5 slightly grindy, -.5 minor unrewarded play time, -.5 creativity inhibitors
Part 1 battling
Very solid Monster RPG battler that encourages synergy and thought in team building and didn't feel particularly unfair at any point. This game is punishing if you are unfamiliar with RPG synergy set ups, but is very easily beatable with almost any team with 2-3 tanks/heal tanks on it. The main issues I have are that if you are constantly given a stream of monster and trying to get them to level up to try new team combos is a bit of a pain this could have been circumvented by just having the player gain xp then have the monsters just have skill points equal to your level. Additionally, the moves and items feel a little on the generic side which is semi-forgivable due to the size of the game but does mean that a lot of monsters feel samey until about level 20 at which point you have mostly picked favorites and don’t want to grind up older monsters unless you are a big numbers fan. My biggest gripe with the gameplay is the battle tower bosses as if you are trying to get that 5-star egg drop you can waste literal hours trying to get a perfect score and not get any gold, xp or items to show for it.

Part 2 platforming
Very solid I never got stuck or locked out anywhere and the timer puzzles were incredibly tight on timing. This did however did lead to me attempting to beat timers that were unbeatable without a mount resulting in about 30-45 minutes of trying to beat timers.

Part 3 Metroidvania
While cool in theory using monster abilities for exploring was often a little confusing on which monster I needed to grab to get through a certain puzzle. While this didn’t block story progress as you only need 2 abilities to beat the game it did making exploring less fun. I would recommend either replacing this mechanic with tools received from bosses rather than trying to grind for a specific type of fish egg. Additionally even if you have a monster specifically meant to get into certain rooms the rewards tend to be pretty lackluster often being random crafting materials or foods I would recommend redoing the chests to contain a unique item and perhaps a “trade deal” contract that allows you to buy new things at the base and leave the generic items as monster drops.

As of writing this review, I've played this game for almost 70 HOURS?! I think it is safe to say that I am addicted to this game. Anyway, I bought this game because I wanted a different experience when it came to the monster taming genre. I was promised a fantasy world where humans and monsters live together within a safe haven from the "Old World." This haven is the Monster Sanctuary, and among the people there are Keepers simultaneously training and preserving the well-being of Monsters. I like this idea as somebody who really loves animals and fantasy creatures.

The game has a beautifully rendered pixel style reminiscent of the 16-bit era, brought to life with fluid animations and wonderful music. The battles that take place throughout the game follow old-style RPGs by playing out certain animations without visibly making contact, and instead rely on special effects to show actions. The game appears to have a clear artistic style that is handled with great care.

A major part of this game is its world building. A lot of effort seemed to have been put on to making the world of Monster Sanctuary as believable and interesting as possible. Despite playing for so long, I have not read that many entries in the Monster Journal. I hope to truly appreciate the work everyone did for the world this game takes place in soon enough.

As for the gameplay, Monster Sanctuary is a monster taming RPG with elements of a "Metroidvania," as it is marketed as. There are a bunch of secrets to discover thanks to the help of the Monsters you tame, and you are free to go anywhere you please, so long as you have the abilities. One is free to take on the Sun Palace before even setting foot into the Stronghold Dungeon. The map is filled with secrets that can only be accessed by certain abilities, so those looking to explore every nook and cranny would be happy to know that you can mark places with labels on your map. This was really handy for me.

The other half of the gameplay is the battling, whether they be against a team of wild Monsters or against another Monster Keeper. Battles start out pretty simple, but later on it can get super complex. The bread and butter of the battles is that they take on a 3-vs-3 turn-based format where every action of one Monster makes the action of the next Monster in order stronger. Applying buffs, healing, shielding and using moves that hit multiple times first is key to delivering devastating blows at the end of your turn to your opponents. There are also debuffs, stacks, auras, and other things that will require you to strategize every battle. Furthermore, the game encourages you to execute battles as efficiently as possible, giving you a rating that influences the loot and money you receive, including Monster eggs to hatch and experiment with on your team. There is never a dull moment in this department.

I'll be honest, the amount of skills and the synergy between your Monsters that you should consider can get very overwhelming. I myself have never really played games that used skill trees to such a degree before. All the RPGs I played before usually had party members with jobs and equipment that influenced what they could do, and the skill trees (plus feeding) add a layer of depth to the gameplay. There will be moments where you will need to stop and go over your Monsters' capabilities. For those used to the laid-back nature of Pokémon (another monster taming RPG that you've probably heard of), you will need to use your brain a lot more, even during the main story. I could see this turning off some people, but for others it yields great satisfaction for understanding and mastering the mechanics.

Even when you're done with the main story, there is still so much to do: battle stronger Champion Monsters, explore hidden worlds, complete the Monster Journal, face off against 20+ Legendary Keepers, and even try your hand at online PvP. As someone driven to 100%'ing the games I play, this game has so much content that will keep me busy. And this game is at least one-third of the price of AAA games (including Pokémon)!

Overall, I am proud to join the Monster Sanctuary. I love exploring new worlds and unlocking the potential of my Monster comrades. I love the presentation and style, and the oodles of content will certainly keep me busy for 70 more hours. This game lit a new fire inside me for the monster taming subgenre of RPGs.

The developers describe this game perfectly as monster taming meets metroidvania mashup. Exploration is done in a side-scrolling pixelated world and many areas are only unlocked after you capture a monster with a certain ability, such as flight or the strength to break down a cracked wall. There's loads of secrets in each area and the game rewards backtracking after you've captured monsters with new abilities.

Defeated monsters have a random chance of dropped eggs when defeated, which is how new monsters are acquired. After defeating really powerful boss monsters in the world, you can return back to base to battle them again at any time. Each battle is scored and graded based on different metrics, and higher grade means better rewards, so more likely to drop an egg. Getting max grade when battling boss monsters is also the only way to acquire eggs of them.

Battles are done in groups of up to three monsters on each side. You can walk around with up to six monsters in your party, three being the active ones that are sent into battle, and one designated as following you around. Every monster has three different skill trees that you can put points into as they level up, but you can never max out all three trees even at max level. The game encourages you to experiment though, since resetting skill point allocation is easy.

It's kind of hard to describe Monster Sanctuary without buzzwords so I'll get them out of the way: this is a SNES JRPG-inspired monster collector game with Metroidvania elements. Somehow, they pulled it off successfully and everything works very well. All of the combat is in environment and you can see (and dodge) your enemies before encounters. While the turn-based combat can be slow at times, there's options to speed up animations and 3v3 means combat rounds are never long anyway. I never found the game tedious because each biome required different approaches to combat; I often found myself swapping in new party members every few hours or returning to old creatures when tough fights demanded it. The game slowly introduced new game systems and concepts that kept surprising me; you rarely get stereotypical "key for a door" abilities and most of your environmental skills are from your monsters. There's a wide range of combat abilities, buffs, debuffs, support skills, and synergies with passives. In fact, there's a bit too much synergy a lot of the time... 

The combat system's flaws become apparent about halfway through the game: any RPG, eastern or western (that I've played at least) will have most buffs and debuffs fall off after a few turns or when they reach a damage threshold. Oddly, there are no time limits on anything here so you can endlessly stack status effects. The more synergistic monsters will not only allow multiple stacks of the same status effect, but can apply multiple buffs or debuffs with the same action in a turn. By the end of the game, you and your opponents will start the battle with a host of status effects before the first turn because of passive abilities. Every fight becomes a race to strip, steal, and dispel enemy buffs while stacking enough debuffs to passively kill your opponents. The last boss was a huge pain who I found even more difficult than the optional bosses I had fought before him. Adding to this fact is that max level is 42 and experience beyond that gets poured into level up consumables means you can't just grind to finish the game like most JRPGs expect you to.

The narrowness of the combat is my only main complaint about this game though. Everything else, from the music, art style, level design, and character customization are all very good. I had a really good time playing most of this game but it got surprisingly difficult near the end. It's a bit odd tonally because the simplistic, predictable story seems to be written for children and yet the gameplay is the probably the sweatiest, neckbeardiest JRPG combat I've ever played. This is the best Metroidvania I've played in a long time... However, I'm giving it a recommendation only on the condition that you realize this game is huge and very challenging. It looks like its aimed for a younger audience but I think I would've given up on this as a child.

Not gonna lie, as a fedora wearing neckbeard, the musketeer hats on the characters are the only reason I considered getting this game at first. 

Did you know that hatching a chicken and then forcing it to fight other chickens is both illegal and immoral? Monster Sanctuary takes place in a world where that is a legal and a respectable way of living, only that instead of chickens it’s mouthless, bipedal, one-eyed beast that sets things on fire with its mind.

Monster Sanctuary feels like a grown up Pokemon. Specially now that Pokemon has become so bloated and un-innovative. 

This is one of my favorite games. Saved me when I was in a huge depression after finding out my wife had a new boyfriend. Pokémon was like that for my wife & I once. We’ve been through the most horrific amount of stress/depression/anxiety in this last couple of years. Life has been unbearable. Monster Sanctuary was a ray of light and such a wonderful distraction. I honestly don’t know where we’d be without it. 

It's absolutely perfect for disenfranchised Pokemon fans like myself. It scratches the same itch as a monster trainer, but with an unbelievable amount of thought and care put into it by the developers. Tying the typical metroidvania upgrades to the monsters you catch is such a natural fit I can't believe it hasn't been done before. The strategy is a perfect balance of being easy enough for casual players, but having an insane cap for anyone who wants to minmax.

It's not often you find a game that is SO good with such little fanfare. Monster Sanctuary is close to one of my favourite games of the genre, it's a fun mix of Metroidvania-style platforming and monster collecting and battling like Pokemon. 

But calling it Pokemon-like its unfair. The combat is nuanced and framed around team building. In three-on-three battles, particularly towards the end game, you frankly will not win without thinking about your tactics and your team. 

And there's not one tactic that is objectively better than the other, whether you like to buff, debuff, stack, brute force, shut down teams with defense, there are so many options to succeed and it depends on your playthrough.

Perhaps my favourite aspect of Monster Sanctuary is that every monster in the game is viable. Even the Monsters you pick up in the first area can take you through to the end of the game. It's all about how you use their unique set of skills to your advantage.

The game is challenging, particularly the end game and post-game, but you can adjust the difficulty settings depending on how you like to enjoy games. 

I cannot recommend this game more highly. The devs are all lovely and very active in the community. Selfishly, I want this game to become wildly popular so that we get a sequel in the future, but also because I think anyone who picks this really well balanced game up will enjoy it, particularly Pokemon fans, RPG fans, Metroidvania fans, and more. Honestly, this game deserves a lot more love than it's gotten, it's very good.

I've had a ton of fun with this game.  The basic gameplay is good, the main story took just the right amount of time, the writing is decent, and the monsters design is really good -- some of these things are down-right adorable, while others are, well, pretty damned cool.  (Favorites of mine have included the Spectral Wolf, Tar Blob, Ninki Nanka, Nightwing, and Krakaturtle)

Combat works more like a traditional RPG than a Pokemon game, which threw me a bit, but I think ends up being better.  At any time, you have six active monsters; when you start combat, you pick a team of 3.  They generally fall into one or more traditional RPG roles, based on how you build them: you've got your physical damage, magic damage, healing, buffing, and barriers.  (Most monsters can potentially perform more than one role, depending on how they're built.)  You've also got items (which give larger bonuses but are rarer) and food (which gives smaller bonuses).  Each monster has four skill trees, and the build-space is fairly complex; some monsters I've found good builds with, some I've found great builds with, and some I'm still working on.

When you're not fighting monster battles, the game is a platformer.  As platformers go, it's fairly conventional, but it's not bad.  While you're going through the world, you can pick one of your monsters to follow you; it will give you a special ability.  These abilities do a lot of the things that unlocked items would do in other platformers: some monsters will lift you, some will let you swim, some you can ride, some will give you a "ghost form" that lets you bypass fights, some will let you burn vines or break walls, and so on.

On the whole, the difficulty level is right where I want it to be.  The monster fights are tough enough that you'll sometimes lose, but they're not impossible or unreasonable.  There are a few boss fights that have thrown me for a loop, but I've managed to get through just about all of them.  The platforming is honestly fairly unchallenging, but I'm OK with that -- not every game needs to be Celeste.

The "quality of life" is also very high.  You can cary as many of your monsters with you as you want -- there's a nursery where you can leave them, but you don't have to, and there's no limit to the number of monsters you can have with you at a time; you can pick any monster to follow you at any time; you can swap monsters into your team at any time; you don't carry damage or conditions from battle to battle; and they start every battle at full mana, so they never run out of "PP".  The biggest things you have to return to town for are changing your outfit, buying more consumables, and upgrading weapons and items.

The game also has PvP, but I have not tried it.

My current team is a rainbow-blob, a magically-levitating turtle with a volcano on it's back, and a rainbow-bird.  Buffs for days!

What would a Pokemon game feel like if it was a metroidvania? That is roughly what Monster Sanctuary is.

For example, even though only your active party (6) gains experience, there are items you can buy or get as drops or rewards which let you level up monsters. Once a monster hits the level cap (42 at the time of writing this review) it continues gaining experience and each "level up" grants one of these items to level up another monster. There are various other examples of similar design choices that seem minor but allow players to have fun with the game's mechanics as opposed to worrying about farming or grinding in order to fully make use of them.

Overall: it's a solid, fun game, especially for any fan of Pokemon or metroidvanias!

While I’ve been a Pokemon fan for many years, good monster collecting games are few and far between. Monster Sanctuary does enough to set itself apart that it can stand on its own, rather than feeling like a watered down version of the original.

The most obvious unique element is the viewpoint: a side-scrolling platformer, rather than a traditional RPG. It compliments this by linking your movement abilities to your monster collecting, kind of an application of Pokemon’s HM system with traditional metroidvania powers.

However, the thing that I appreciated most was the customization. Each monster has a unique skill tree and up to three variations that grant a passive ability and new stat array. Building an effective party requires utilizing all of these elements to find synergistic ways to answer challenges.

While I enjoyed the game as a whole, there were elements that fell a bit short. The difficulty curve felt inconsistent (possibly due to party makeup and play-style choices, but it was noticeable). The metroidvania elements were sometimes applied to your character, but usually required you to catch specific new monsters. Farming items for equipment upgrades felt necessary, but repetitive.

Shortcomings aside, this game was wonderful. I had a lot of fun playing with all of the systems and building new parties. It did something unique and it scratched an itch.

123780831.review:
Are you the kind of person who gets super attached to their monsters/units and is constantly anxious that they'll have to leave them behind when they become obsolete? Well, here it's entirely possible to beat the final boss with the very first blob you've hatched in the tutorial [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2874678373](proof)[/url]. In fact, I'd say that every single monster is viable - as long as you play into its strengths. No need to worry about IV, EV, no endless grinding; just team building and strategy.

The game almost feels more like Monster Train than Pokemon; it's less about having the perfect monster with just the right moves and exploiting weaknesses - rather, it's about creating those cascading synergies of destruction which hopefully will end your opponent before they end you. Yes, exploiting weaknesses is a thing here as well, but it's just one piece of the strategic puzzle - one that sometimes is better discarded in favour of a more synergic course of action.

Alas, this is also something that can be seen by many as bad; You see, for a big chunk of the game you can get away with playing Monster Sanctuary as if it was Pokemon. Buffs, debuffs and synergies are just nice-to-haves, but we know it's all about that "super effective" raw crit damage. Right? Well, at a certain moment - which, sadly, is in the final stretch of the game - you're being told: Stop. You're playing the game wrong. Here's an opponent that actually uses buffs and debuffs strategically, and they will [i]decimate[/i] you if you don't have a properly built team. If you explore a lot, you'll probably run into one of the super champions before then - and they'll teach you this lesson a little earlier; but you'll still have to get down to it, read the skill descriptions and make a team that's got good synergy.

That said, the team building is as streamlined as possible. Each monster has 3-5 separate skill trees which usually focus on different possible roles; you can immediately see all of them and plan ahead. You can also very easily respec your monster, or hatch a new one which will be only slightly behind your strongest level. And no worries; you can save teams for later use - and there's more slots than you can possibly need.

There's a lot more to say about the battles, but enough is enough. You get the idea. It's great, and generally grindless. Let's talk about the aesthetic for a bit.

It looks great, that's plain to see. Every monster is fully animated - walking, jumping, attacking. And the monster compendium has wonderful, detailed pictures of each and every single monster. On a Cute/Cool scale, they tend to fall towards Cute, but that doesn't prevent many of them from being cool as well. Areas are varied and each of them has their own unique feel, even if from a pure level design perspective they're more or less the same. 

And the music? It's a bit of a mixed bag in my opinion. Some early game pieces feel... I don't know, uninspired? But as you keep going, the music gets better and better, all the way to the end. One piece in particular has a very specific feel - it's meticulously made to sound like it's from Terranigma, an old SNES classic which happens to be a favourite of mine. It's so spot on that I refuse to believe it's a coincidence - and why would it be? Monster Sanctuary is a German game, and the biggest fan community of Terranigma is also in Germany.

The story is also a little weird. There's nothing wrong with it per se - I enjoyed it, and there's a lot of interesting lore everywhere. Something about the way the characters speak is... unusual. And the story itself is very plain, not many twists and no real structure... in a way, it feels less like a story and more like something that's actually happening. That's a good thing? Maybe? Unusual, like I said.

All in all, the game is fantastic. I enjoyed it greatly, and towards the end I simply couldn't put it down. I'd even go so far to call this game a masterwork - at least as far as its general design and individual systems are concerned. If we lived in a fair, meritocratic world, Monster Sanctuary would be death knell of Pokemon; kids would wear Blob backpacks to school and we'd have a Hollywood release of Detective Catzerker. Instead we live in a world ruled by marketing budgets and trend-driven design; luckily, you can escape this world at least a little bit and play Monster Sanctuary.

And remember, love your Blobs, and they will love you back!

Seeing as I've clocked in over 150 hours into this, I cannot recommend this game enough.

At this point, I've already completed the game four times, yet this game practically infinite replay-ability, I keep coming back to it while trying out different strategies.

I've already seen many comments talking about it in regards to a platforming experience, so I'm going to take sometime to compare and contrast it to Pokemon for the fans who are coming over from the creature collector side of Steam.

Pros:
-The main selling point of this game is that every single monster within it can be good. The people in charge of balancing the game deserve so much credit, I say this with full certainty, every single monster in this game can be the star of your team. From monsters found on the very first route to monsters that evolve into something else (monsters that evolve don't necessarily become better, they just gain access to different skill sets), there isn't a single monster that is a waste of a team slot. (Unlike where as in pokemon, you very rarely keep the beginning route pokes and you almost always hinder yourself by not evolving your mons).
-Depth of Combat. Do you like the amount of strategy that goes on in competitive pokemon, but you get tired of the actual story being too easy, MS throws that right out the window. This game starts out easy enough so you can get used to the style and then consistently pumps out more and more depth that only ever add to the experience, yet never feel cluttered. 
-Difficulty. This game is significantly more difficult than any pokemon game, if you are looking for a more challenging yet rewarding experience, this is 100% your best bet.
-Story. Creature Collectors that have an actual story besides, "Get 8 badges, beat the elite four, and become the champion" will always have my heart. This is a story that while not as impressive as titles outside of the genre, absolutely stands up to titles within the genre and kept me on my toes the first time around.
-Non-Linear Progression. One of my favorite things that I've learned after playing through the game several times is that the you can pretty much choose how you want to progress through the middle section of the game. This game is split into various little regions that have a unique storytelling aspect, but all connect to a overarching story. One you get past the first area and start making your way into the second area, about 50% of the other regions open up, allowing you to take a non-linear progression through the map. The best part of this being that the regions will scale to your level. For instance, my first two runs I went through the Dungeon Area second and always had monsters level 6-10 there. However, recently I've been going to that area later in my playthroughs and I've been getting anywhere from 10-25 (depending on how late I get there). This really helps in making every run feel unique.

Cons:
-This game infamously has a massive difficulty spike. Depending on what kind of team you're running you may experience it earlier or later, but all in all, there is a 90% chance that you will feel solid in your team, and then there will be fight that makes you re-plan your entire team. Now that isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it can be frustrating on a first-run through to hit that wall.
-Reliance on Debuffs. This is another thing that may not be a negative thing for some, it might just be more different some similar creature collection games. From my experience, if you want long-term success in this game you have to base it around debuffs as you won't be able to do enough damage by pure damage alone. This is something that I initially disliked, but it has grown on me quite a bit...so there's that.

TLDR: 
Q. Is this game worth $20?
A. 1000% yes. I would gladly pay double that price simply due to how great of an experience this game is (and I still plan to play for many more hours too!)

The Metroidvania stuff did kind of annoy me occasionally, however falling off a platform or hitting spikes or whatever was never much of a detriment as you just pop up on the last safe ground you were on with no repercussions, allowing you to retry as many times as you need to very quickly with no downside. The map also has a handy little marker you can set as well, so anytime i found something i couldn't do yet, i would just mark it on the map, label it what it was that was stopping me from going that way, and when i found the thing that let me pass it, it was easy enough to get back there and go do the thing.

Where this game REALLY hooked me though was the amazing creature collector side of the gameplay. There are SO many build options for your team and strategies you can do. And because your monsters have skill trees, you can even make multiple teams with the same monsters work completely differently. The synergies you could line up between your monsters attacks and even what position you placed them on your team could really make a difference. There is so much more to the strategy than just "Hit the enemy with the element it's weak to" that so many other creature collector games pretty much completely revolve around.

Since you hatch new monsters just a couple levels below the level of the ones in your party, switching out your monsters and your team strategy was quick and easy and the game showers you with level badges that you can give to your underleveled monsters and get them to just one level below your team as well so even if you want to try out that one monster that you have had in your inventory for a while and neglected, it's a trivial matter to get them into fighting shape again and play around with your build. You can also carry ALL of your monsters with you at all times instead of having to go back to a PC or some stupid garbage to switch out your team. All these quality of life decisions just make experimentation and build testing that much more fun and doable.

All in all, this game hooked me so hard that even though i'm not typically the kind of person to replay games over and over again, I can't stop thinking about this game even after i have done everything. Seriously considering doing a new game+ run.

I gotta show some love to Monster Sanctuary, which I haven't been able to put down since I started playing it a few days ago.

It's a mix of monster collecting/raising and platformer exploration with light puzzles. So Pokemon meets Metroidvania.

The controls are FANTASTIC so the platforming part is a blast and using the various monsters' unique skills to reach new areas is fun. There are puzzles that are interesting though not super difficult to mix things up.

They also released a massive expansion to the game for free recently choosing to allow people to tip the dev team if they liked it. I love stuff like that and try to pay more than I paid for the game to show appreciation and encourage more development.

122351018.review:
[h1]Short Review[/h1]

Ni no Kuni, Digimon, Folklore plus many many more games are apart of the "monster trainer" genre which has existed now for a long time but none has come remotely close to the success and popularity as Pokémon. Even when Pokémon products are regarded in utter disdain (Sword & Shield games) the franchise seemingly gets a pass with droves of children and adults willing to pay money over fist for whatever they can get with their outstretched sweaty palms full of money.

Monster Sanctuary (MS) is a game that deserves the attention that that yellow electric mouse gets and more. Monster Sanctuary is worth your time, money and repays you in all the ways you'd want, then some.

[h1]Longer Review[/h1]

Battles are turn based like so many games in this genre but they're also considerably more complex than what you've likely experienced if your reference point is Pokémon. Every monster in the game has a skill tree with 3 - 4 branching paths. The branching paths fall into offensive, defensive and support. Typically, each monster will have 2 or all 3 of these branching paths with several monsters being more particular/unique for example, Toxiquus (a seahorse looking monster) has a team buffing tree, a wind attacking combined with healing tree and two specific yet different poison trees. Once maxed level, you'll notice you haven't and cannot unlock everything in all the paths.

The item Skill Resetter which is insanely cheap and often found whilst exploring, can be used at any time on any monster to reset their skill trees. This allows you to respec whatever skills you'd like, allowing for lots of experimentation.

On top of this each monster has their own stats waiting to be manipulated. They can equip their own equipment (which can be upgraded), have food passives and a Light or Dark passive using a Shift Stone allowing for huge customization of playstyle. There're many Toxiquus but this one, Curly Bubble, is mine.

Each monster naturally has their own strengths and weaknesses so, with all the above combined, it's correct to quickly assume that each monster has a lot going on. Now multiple all that by three and you have a single battle, multiple all of that by six and you have a team battle. That's 6 selected from a pool of 111 different monsters.

Outside of all the tinkering and battling you'll be wanting to "Catch 'Em All" (the monsters). This is done via finding monsters when exploring the areas and simply battling them. If you perform well enough you'll be rewarded with a rating. If that rating is high enough, you'll get a monster egg to hatch. You'll be able to hunt down boss monsters and hidden monsters as well as your standard monsters.

Newly hatched monsters are hatched at the same level as your current team meaning you don't have to grind away for hours leveling up a new monster only to find that it doesn't gel with you for whatever reason. Considering what I typed about respecing monsters, it's extremely clear that the devs want players to be able to experiment with a wide variety of monsters quickly and easily. They've definitely done that.

[h1]Metroidvania[/h1]

Outside of the "monster trainer" tag MS is played in a Metroidvania style world with running, jumping, pulling levers and acquiring double jump etc. MS adds to this gameplay style by finding a perfectly fitting way to customize the Metroidvania gameplay style to it's own theme. All the monsters that you've been collecting on your journey can also be used to navigate the environment. Found a ledge that you can't reach, perhaps your Vaero monster can help you reach it. Can't reach that treasure chest because of a diamond block, maybe Asura can help you out etc.

[h1]Game Modes[/h1]

Everything that I've typed so far is the core game. Outside all that there's also challenge duels, PVP with leaderboards, infinite battle mode and you can replay any boss monster battle until your heart is content. When you've finished the game to 100% (like myself) you can go for New Game + which allows you to keep your monsters, certain items and equipment. If that wasn't enough, additionally and optionally you can also turn on "Nuzlocke" style options when you start a new game having beaten it once or when you select New Game +.

[h1]Last Thoughts[/h1]

MS is a great game with loads of content. The game has become so popular in my home that we've also bought it on the Switch so that I and my son (or the Mrs) can play at the same time.

I completely recommend this to everyone especially if you're jaded by the Pokémon franchise. MS is a fantastic game that is truly as deep as you want to take it and worth every moment.

So! Approximately 35 hours and I completed the game 100% (at least in regards to the metrics I have available. I have all the monsters, all the outfits, full map completion, fought every boss.

Absolutely great game. Not perfect, by any means. The balancing can be a little shaky at times, some of the fights you get into early on can feel extremely unfair. But learning the system, making a few good teams, and then working your way forward piece by piece got me a momentum that eventually led to me sweeping the whole damn game. Felt good.

Lots of care went into this, and it's very evident. The areas, music, monster sprites...
[spoiler]There's a friggin Orca with legs. You can ride it.[/spoiler]

[b]PROS[/b]
Great pixel art.
Great music.
Generally fun gameplay.
World feels good to explore. [spoiler]The content added in the Forgotten World DLC is my favorite. I loved feeling like [i]I[/i] was the one doing the exploring, rather than going through areas that other characters had explained. A great sense of mystery.[/spoiler]

[b]THE MIXED BAG[/b]
The skill trees have NAUSEATING depth. So many possible pairings and builds that it can be really easy to get lost. Some of the most powerful combos aren't immediately obvious, and a lot of builds that sound good in theory can get you totally screwed, and you feel like you've wasted some investment in equipment, skill resetters, etc. The freedom to choose how you build is excellent, but the game does punish you for building poorly, even on the lower difficulty.

[b]CONS[/b]
The game's difficulty seems to fluctuate wildly between bosses, optional content, and exploration. Some areas you'll breeze right on through, only to get absolutely stomped by the boss. Some areas, you'll just get stomped in the field, only to find that your team hard counters the boss.
[spoiler]The keeper duels in particular can be a bit awful. The first one you're introduced to, against Will, is almost guaranteed to clap you, unless you happen to have the right build early on. I have yet to interact with anyone who has won that one first try.[/spoiler]
It can be a bit confusing at times.
(Note this is not a dig at the devs. Balancing a game with this much complexity is hard as hell.)


TL;DR
Is the game worth it? Yes, definitely. Just don't be afraid to take breaks. Marathoning this game can get frustrating, and sometimes, hitting a roadblock in a particular fight can be downright rage inducing. But for the lovely metroidvania elements, the beautiful design, and the oodles and canoodles of care that went into this one, it has [i]got[/i] to be a yes from me, dog.

I got this game on sale to scratch a Pokemon itch (and I'm a fan of Metroidvania), but this is not what I expected. This is a great game. I found that the 3v3 battle structure made for much more interesting combat and strategy, which is sorely lacking in the broader genre. Each monster has its own individual skill trees which expand and unlock new synergies as you level, providing a nice learning curve as the game progressed. I thought I would be able to take my starting few monsters and power my way through the game, but I hit a significant wall and needed to revamp to take advantage of the synergies available and have a more balanced team. This is where the game truly shines.

The Metroidvania style exploration is interesting. It's not crucial to the game design by any means, but the developers melded monster monster collection with exploration, which was a nice touch. It relies a little more on the monster collection aspect than something like Pokemon, since certain monsters were necessary to open specific secrets, but the collection method is easier. There isn't any "hunting for random encounters," as they are all structured, and actually obtaining monster eggs is somewhat straightforward. The puzzles themselves are simple and a little repetitive (mostly a series levers), but they don't feel cumbersome or frustrating, though there is definitely some room for improvement.

While there is a lot of depth in team-building, there is little incentive to continually experiment, as building one strong team can easily carry you through the game (and even the higher level end-game content). I needed to only make one small adjustment for the most difficult encounters once I had a good team. With the amount of end-game challenges and how simple it is to build another team (as new monsters scaling in level with you), I would like to see more end-game content that relied on specific strategies or limited you to smaller monster pools in order to explore more of the depth in the game.

There's a lot of content here, and this is a very polished product. I hope the developers decide to make a sequel down the road, building on the foundation they've built with this game. Definitely give this a try, especially if you like the team building/collection aspects of similar games.

I never wanted a Metroidvani/monster Collector combo game, nor did i think they would work together, but genuinely one of the best games i've played from 2020. The mixing of Gotta Catch 'em pokemon with the movement upgrades required to make the back tracking and exploration of Metroidvania rewards is fantastic and well done. 1000% more balanced than pokemon since every single monster is viable at all stages of the game. some are better than others obviously, but don't think you know just by looking.  (Blob and Magmapillar are legit top tier mons) and some monsters that aren't pitch hitters can be fantastic with the right team. I used Ucan (crab monster) for all of the hardest content in the game as 1 of my main damage carries and he is considered D or below tier so you legit don't have to worry. That doesn't mean it's easy either though, the monster are all just designed with a power floor that makes them useful, some just have higher ceilings. I also have to say that the BIGGEST PRO of this game is the QOL features this game has. I do not have a single complaint when it comes to, menus, movement controls, synergies, combat, leveling, collecting monsters, optimizing and experimenting with your monsters and teams. Mor Rai has cut out all of the pointless bloat to these feature and the game plays and feel rewarding at all times. All new monsters are guaranteed to just be 2 levels below the rest, you can carry and infinite number of monsters with you so you don't need to worry about changing monsters for battling or exploration, resetting skill trees can be done easily and infinitely, losing and dying has almost no punishment or inconvenience whatsoever so you can feel free to experiment or try again without stressing or losing progress, Map markers so you can save info for later when you have the right ability, the ability to speed up combat and other convenient features that just work. They preserved everything you like about both Genre's seamlessly while also trimming the fat.

My only cons to this game are:
Barely a real Story 
Uninteresting Characters
Some Monster Names and designs

The Story is incredibly Simple and doesn't even really have a message or meaning just a vehicle to get you from point A to point B so you can catch more monsters and explore the map, (post game makes it more interesting but that's a low bar and leaves you expecting DLC, WHICH i can't wait for) and the characters aren't even really Archetypes, There are only 3 characters that can even claim to have personalities, Nerd guy, Pompous Prick, and Old man teacher guy and now you know everything you need to know about them. Every other character in the entire game exist to just tell you a hint to a secret or to go to a place to do a thing. Neither of these Genres really require either of these to big successful and they aren't going to stop me from loving this game, but there is obviously room for improvement here.

The last complaint is, of course, just personal opinion but Monster names like Rocky for a rock with legs, and Goblin Wizard for a goblin wizard just don't do it for me. i would say about 40% of the monsters need better names and maybe 10% would be better off removing. I don't like monsters that somehow hatch out of an Egg with a claymore in hand or a Barrel with wings and that's it. (Ornithopter, dumb name as well, is literally a barrel with wings, no face no mouth, nothing that even indicates it is anything more than a barrel some stapled cardboard to) I also don't like the goblins or steam golems just because they feel like... not monster but people if you know what i mean so it feels weird. I know part of this is bias off pokemon and digimon and this game is trying to be a classic RPG monster but even so that is my preference

Overall this is an easy 9/10 game and i'll recommend to everyone i know. Please give me more Moi Rai

I liked this game for most of it. The monster skill trees are interesting, and the platforming puzzles are generally (with a couple of exceptions here and there) challenging without being overly punishing. However, towards the end I started hating this game with a burning passion. A couple of battles just felt completely overpowered and unplayable unless you have a very specific counter team for it. Like, the team that has carried you through the whole game is suddenly totally helpless just for one fight. To me, this was bad enough to flip my review from positive to negative, precisely because all the positive aspects of the game build up this impression that you have so much freedom and agency to choose your team and playstyle, but in the end it suddenly pulls the rug out from under you in a very jarring and frustrating way, and the primary team comp you have put so much thought into putting together and refining suddenly becomes completely useless. 

More specifically, I'd never had any problems with compulsory story battles up to that point, but in the late game against Zosimos, my strongest DPS with the right elemental advantage (and the stacking status afflictions to match) suddenly couldn't even damage the squishiest enemy monster enough to make even the slightest dent in the downright ridiculous amount of PASSIVE heals and shields. They literally healed to full, through both direct damage and damage over time, with a huge chunk of shield every single round while still using all three actions to attack, and there was nothing I could do at all. And that was with heals and shields being nerfed by a passive aura from another monster in my team. I don't see a point in there being so many monsters to choose from when some fights are completely untouchable unless you have a specific 'correct' lineup. It felt like my choices during the battle didn't make any difference at all; no matter what actions I chose and in what order I was doomed to lose miserably just because I don't have whichever specific monster that was supposed to be the 'right' answer. I'd be okay if this was for one of the optional champions (e.g. my team also couldn't do anything with the Ascendant, but I didn't mind just skipping that), but to lock main story content behind something like that is just needlessly frustrating. Completely ruined the experience for me; it was like running into a brick wall without warning, and I lost all motivation to continue playing.

I wanted to drop the difficulty just to bypass that one annoying fight, but the difficulty settings are also completely useless. I dropped it all the way down to Casual and there was ZERO difference. Everything played out exactly the same. What's the point of having that as a setting if there's no difference between the difficulty levels?

121657006.review:
This game pairs mechanics from metroidvanias and creature collectors in very interesting ways, and it does a far better job at both than it has any right to.   As a pure metroidvania it benefits from tying the exploration abilities to creatures, because thorough exploration and collecting can get you access to new areas very rapidly, with quite a lot of postgame content being unlockable well before you actually reach the end of the game.

The levels of enemies are tied to map exploration when you first arrive in the room, so while there is some degree of "intended progression" attached to areas, and some areas have relatively high minimum levels, the level progression is likely to be reasonably smooth for most of your run, and you'll never enter a new area and find that the enemies are hopelessly weak because you missed a low level area 10 hours earlire.

The creatures have pretty robust skill trees, with quite a lot of differentiation.  The combat system seems specifically designed to allow you to use synergies in ways that seem extremely overpowered, and mastering different combat styles feels quite fun.  

I created a bird of doom that stacked basically every possible debuff in the game onto enemies in a single round, using a mixture of their skills, auras from their allies, and accessories.  This was paired with abilities that reduce enemy damage dealt to my party for each debuff on them to take a party that seemed quite squishy, and make them remarkably sturdy.  

Having the doom bird be the lynchpin of my combat strategy, that everything else revolved around, was not because the bird itself is that out of control.  I found an aesthetic I liked early, and leaning hard into that aesthetic was extremely mechanically rewarding.

Overall the combat system, collection mechanics, and metroidvania elements worked together in an extremely satisfying way.  Certainly the best creature collector game I've ever played, and one of the best turn based combat systems I've seen in general.

121573824.review:
I played this game on the Switch and rebought it here on a discount to support the devs a bit more, which is why my play time is not 50 hours.

Monster Sanctuary is a very solid game with a lot of content (took me about 50 hours to complete the story), an awesome skill system for your monsters and a decent amount of challenge, which I would recommend to everybody, who likes Pokemon, but wants something that requires more strategy to beat, to try out. Unfortunately it doesn’t do a good job at giving you the right expectations to enjoy the challenging parts immediately.
At the start, the game teaches you, how the combat system works and then leaves you alone with your monsters and their skill trees, which I enjoyed a lot. Reading the skills always makes you think: “Oh, that sounds useful and combos well with that other thing. I want that.”, which makes every level up exciting. The same thing is true for new monsters, which have even more new abilities for you to get excited about.
Of cause, this can’t go on for ever, since there are only so many abilities. So strategy and challenge have to take over, but the way they did was not very enjoyable. It was basically one fight, which was a big difficulty spike. Of cause I thought a bit about my team before, but losing this fight multiple times (which there is no punishment for), while I beat everything before in the first few tries made me question, if my team was bad. Or maybe I was just getting unlucky, maybe my level was to low. I just didn’t know and that didn’t feel good. Through out the next fights I slowly got into the right mindset of expecting to lose the first attempts and using them to find out, what my opponents monsters are doing, so I knew what monsters to take out first etc. the next times. That way I was able to beat the later fights (exempt the finale) in 1-10 tries while being underleveled, so I don’t thing the game is to difficult, the difficulty curve is just bad, but I can’t think of a good way to fix it either, without having a bad new player experience.
An other weak point of the game are the characters and the world. Part of that could be, because I took a longer break from playing the game in the middle of the story, but the characters always felt a little flat to me and the areas didn’t quite feel like a connected world and not very immersive. But that could also just be me. I don’t know.
In any case, apart from those two issues the game is great. There are a lot of monsters, that all feel different and capable, a lot of interesting abilities to discover and use and only one music track, that in my opinion was not in between good and awesome. There is also a new game+, that I haven't tried yet, that even has a build in randomizer and perma death option, which they released in a free update, they definitely could have charged money for.
So, as I sad, if you are a Pokemon fan, I recommend you giving this a try. Just don’t expect Pokemon levels of difficulty.

120597495.review:
Take everyone's favourite monster collecting game, give each creature multiple skill trees, scale up battles to 3v3 fights, then slap that onto a metroidvania backdrop and you have Monster Sanctuary.

This game features fairly deep, tactical combat, where buffs and debuffs are just as—if not more—important than your attack skills. Building a balanced team that provides a strong mix of utility, healing, durability, and damage output takes some finesse, but the process is fun all the way through. Thanks to new monsters you hatch always being within a few levels of your strongest creature, and a good supply of level up badges (this game's version of rare candy), it is relatively easy to try new monsters on your team. You can also save multiple teams and quickly switch between them (outside of combat of course).

In addition to having multiple build pathways, each creature can also equip a weapon and three accessories to further increase their stats and abilities. Equipment can be upgraded to enhance stat bonuses, and special rare equipment can have unique effects. I enjoyed how many paths one could feasibly take to reach success. I personally enjoyed emphasising burning away enemy buffs and stacking shields on my own team to keep a glass cannon alive and bombarding the enemy.

What can sometimes put me off of metroidvania games is the feeling that I am constantly backtracking. I'm happy to say this is not generally an issue here. While I did find myself returning to previously explored areas a few times, it was usually relatively low hassle, and was seldom necessary. While some backtracking is required to progress, in most cases the reward for returning to previously explored areas is extra upgrade materials for your equipment, or occasionally finding some new monsters.

I went into this expecting a reasonably quick game lasting between 20 and 30 hours, but I spent nearly 60 hours before completing the main story and hitting the end credits. I'm happy to share that I never felt like I had to grind, and naturally reached max level at the very end. There is a New Game+ option that I have not yet tried, and before I do there is still a significant amount of additional content to explore.

This game packs heaps into it. I never even touched the competitive multiplayer or several of the optional quests/explorable spaces. Overall it's a great game and well worth picking up if you enjoy RPGs in any form.
