A solid critter-catcher with charming art, fun battle mechanics and a thought-out leveling system. I've already sunk several hours into this game and catching all the little monsters is really fun! There's a diverse set of skills and types so you can really mix up your team however you want. However, when I saw there was a frog as a starter choice, I knew I would be sold. 

My only complaint is that the platforming can occasionally be pretty frustrating, but it's not terribly punishing most of the time and there have only been a few items I've had to leave behind. From an accessibility standpoint, this can make for a feeling of slow progress as timing jumps isn't always easy for disabled players, but I found I have been able to get through most areas without too much difficulty. 

I love the art and the creatures; you can tell a lot of love was put into their design. Being able to unlock different types makes it all the better, with different skillsets and colors to choose from! The game also does a good job of not dumping it all on you at once so you have time to learn the mechanics. 

Creatures also have other utilities on the map, like being able to solve puzzles, float the player or swim, and I found that made a lot of the platforming feel more fun and less like a slog through a level. Plus, it's really cute to see your little monster friend follow you around the map! 

While I can't say anything about the end game story, I like the one that's been presented so far. The game does a good job of making you feel connected to the world and invested in what happens to the monsters and the keep, and I'm looking forward to seeing where it goes! 

I think this game is polished enough to warrant full price, it seems very reasonable for the amount of content and I think it's very promising that the devs seem committed to releasing free DLC so as to keep the PVP aspect of the game (which seems entirely optional) balanced and fun for all players. Definitely a thumbs up from me!

Most battles are in the wild; fighting 3 monsters at a time with 3 of your own. However, as part of the main story and some end-game content, there are 6v6 battles against other 'keepers' (trainers). The 6v6 fights require you to have a proper line-up. Tanks, support, and DPS are all important factors in a well-oiled team. The AI opponents will have them, you're expected to as well. There are also boss battles, which aren't very hard, but 5-starring them certainly can be.

This game is challenging. There was a point while playing where I audibly said, "this game sucks ass." It wasn't until I stopped acting like a gaming journalist and started acting like an adult human being that it clicked with me. By the end game, I was beating the "Legendary Keepers" with a total of ~10 different monsters, swapped in as needed based on enemy team comp. You really DO NOT need to Google guides to beat the 6v6 fights, but there is more trial and error than some people are willing to sit through; which is very understandable. My advice is to learn from the AI, their team comps and synergies.

Biggest con for me is that dodge chance is extremely annoying, especially given how tanky some of the monsters can get. It's somewhat fair since the player has access to it as well, but the fights can feel like a slog at times when over half your damage is whiffed. Also, it feels like monsters should just hatch at the Avg team level, rather than 2-3 below your highest. There isn't a purpose for them not to, it frustrates people.

Overall it's a pretty good game that served to scratch that creature-team-building itch. Would probably play great on the Steam Deck as well, if you've got one.

120039443.review:
I'm a huge fan of monster collecting games, and an even bigger fan of games with vast skill trees - so to know each individual monster in [b]Monster Sanctuary[/b] has its own individual, randomised skill tree was an immediate pull to me.

The game is genuinely fun to play and explore, and the problem-solving aspect of working out which monster will help you overcome various environment obstacles was frustrating at times, but easily done thanks to the list of abilities each monster has being easily visible on the party screen. The fact you can carry dozens and dozens of monsters on you at once (as opposed to the usual 'party' concept of around 6 members at once) and make teams on the fly to fight with is great, as it saves unnecessary trips back to the 'daycare' area you unlock later in the game.

The longer you play the campaign, the more and more monsters you end up with in your party - juggling their abilities, synergies, pros, cons etc. - and this can be quite overwhelming at times.

While this is more most likely down to my own skill, I will say that at the time of writing, I still haven't defeated one of the 'main' storyline bosses, due to it being such a (seemingly impossible) difficult fight. There are a few mechanics which don't make too much sense to me - such as only two of your monsters being able to move on the first turn of a boss battle, as opposed to all three of theirs (meaning they always start with an advantage, so in difficult boss battles you're on the losing foot instantly) - but certain bosses have predetermined synergies and upgrades applied to their monsters which make them [i]brutally[/i] difficult. For me, it went from a fun monster-collecting and party-building game to a frustrating back-and-forth of trial and error with different parties, items, armour, and above all - luck - to try and beat the final boss. However, the furthest I got was about halfway through his monsters, at which point the cumulative buffs he'd built up on his monsters make them practically immortal and nothing I could even make a dent on.

I do have friends who have already beaten this boss battle and moved on however, but claim it's down to having a very specific party with very specific synergies - which to me sadly takes a lot of the magic away. If there's such a vast collection of monsters to collect and train, but then only one or two decently powerful combinations that can actually defeat a final boss, it feels the same as only being able to defeat the Elite Four in Pokemon with legendaries. If I want to try and beat Elite Four Aaron with three Dittos and an levelled up starter, I should be able to, however slim the odds.

Regardless - combined with the free recently released DLC, I went back to the game and continued playing and exploring, and did still find it enjoyable despite not having completed the main storyline.

In short; Monster Sanctuary is a vast exploration and party-building game with tons of detailed skill trees, but some of the boss encounters seem far too difficult for the casual player.

This is one of the best games I've ever played, and probably the best monster-catching game you'll find in the genre, let alone Steam. The games simplistic style and comparatively small monster count (111 at the time of writing this) betray it's complex but fun leveling and skill system. Because of this, the game can be VERY challenging, especially once you hit late game where if you don't know what you're doing you'll get your butt kicked by just about anything you bump into. However, this game does an excellent job of easing you into the different mechanics of the game, and by the time you reach the third or fourth area you should have a good grasp of how the game works if you have good reading comprehension, unlike me.

        Now since this game is difficult, I've put a mini-guide below if you want it. However, if you do not, then all you'll need to take from me is that this game is VERY much worth $20 and I cannot recommend it enough, it's a good 30 hours of fun and I think most people will enjoy it, including you.

        Each monster has its strengths, weaknesses, and one to three areas of profession; healer, support, tank, buffer, debuffer, and of course the magic/physical DPS, and its your job to balance them out and create teams that synergize with each other based on their passives, abilities, stats. And the cherry on top? If you ever make a mistake and put a skill point somewhere that you don't want that messes up your strategy, the game has you covered by giving you access to infinite skill reset items VERY early on in the game at the stronghold shop at the cost of a handful of gold, meaning if you wanted you could just mix and match skills till you can come up with an unstoppable monster child of death and destruction that even the gods themselves fear.

        This game is VERY akin to Metroid in its platforming, and different monsters have different explore abilities. You'll want to keep tabs on which monster does what as the game doesn't tell you on their status screen, it only tells you when you try to switch your active explore monster. (A + D on Keyboard, L + R on Xbox controller) Another thing about exploring: The map. Or more specifically, the marker tool for that map (Spacebar for PC, A for controller) which allows you to keep notes on things you find but don't have access to, like elemental switches and unbreakable walls. If this was explained in game, then I either missed an NPC I didn't talk to or I wasn't paying attention in one of the cutscenes dialogues, which is unlikely but I've done dumber things. Its very important you keep tabs because these inaccessible spots lead to optional bosses, unique equipment, and items that can 'permanently' buff your monsters like rare food, or items that actually permanently upgrade your monsters like skill potions.

        And that's it! Thanks for reading, and I hope this review was helpful in one way or another. Happy hunting!

An innovative game with metroidvania-style exploration/platforming and customizable Pokemon-like gameplay (but with many [i]good[/i] differences). It has beautiful pixel art and seems relatively bug-free.

There are a lot of interesting, synergistic teams to make, though I feel like (unlike Pokemon) it's a lot harder to re-assemble your team to fit in a new monster or strategy, which caused me to stick to one working strategy for most/all of the game. This can lead to fairly repetitive gameplay unless the player wants to go through the tedium of:

* Figuring out which monsters fit into the new strategy, including checking dark/light forms
* Leveling the 3-6 monsters (using ample consumable items)
* Equipping monsters with 4 items each (including assembling/leveling the items if necessary)
* Feeding monsters 3 items each
* Allocating skill trees (of 20-40+ points depending on where you're at)

Due to this, I used monsters I found in the first few areas through the entirety of the game (if curious: Magmapillar, Catzerker, Tanuki). I tried poking around at using a few others (as minor changes), but they seemed significantly worse than the lame setup team I'd been running.

Still, this game has a lot of content, clean animations, nice pixel art, and is just overall well-put-together.

Also, you can set combat speed to 3x.

Monster Sanctuary is essentially a Castlevania: SotN metroidvania with Pokemon style monster capture and old school JRPG turned based party combat.

118455311.review:
As you can perhaps tell, I love this game. It hits a lot of the nostalgic notes that recent pokemon remakes aim for, and it does it a lot better. If you strike out the more "filler" mons that gen 1 pokemon had, you've even got more monster diversity. Adding light metroidvania elements is a lot of fun, and encourages you to keep a relatively diverse group of monsters around, even if you aren't using all of them to fight.

The AI is much smarter than it is in a game like pokemon as well, which is always a good touch. The distinction between battles against champion monsters vs keeper duels also provides a nice contrast, giving you two different flavors of high-level play. The battle system looks simpler than pokemon, but in reality I'd say it's just easier to parse and easier to optimize. Depth-wise, what's really happening is that you're exchanging a prediction-oriented playstyle for a build-oriented playstyle, which suits me quite well on a personal level. Every monster is unique, and they all play a little bit differently and synchronize with their teammates a little bit differently.

Finally, while I don't personally go in for the multiplayer matchmaking, it's important to note that there is a robust scene for it with a well-developed meta, and the devs are quite attentive to balance issues, both in terms of power and in terms of playstyle diversity. The post-release changes to how buffs work are a big example here; buffing-oriented teams on release tended to just spam as many copies of whatever buffs they had access to, where debuff teams were built to focus on different kinds of debuffs, all of which had slightly different effects. Since release, many of the new auras and other skills have focused on buffs in one way or another, with particular attention going to skills that add flavor to specific buffs along the lines of the skills that have done the same for debuffs since the early access period. The game's discord server is quite active and friendly, and I'd recommend joining it if you're interested in the multiplayer.

I love this game. It took me almost 60 hours to do almost everything the game has to offer (sans New Game+ and one cheevo). The story and most of the graphics are a plain ok, but everything else the game has it's really good. The battles are great, most monsters are useful for something or in certain comps. You can play the same monster in different ways through skill trees. It does take a while when you first start to have that really fun rush because of all the possibilities at your disposal. Initially, some monsters are too weak and you'll have to play a while to tame better ones. This is mostly because the equipment you'll get at the beginning won't be a lot of help, but the closer you get to the endgame the more possibilities you acquire. 

Initially I wasn't really into most of the monsters because of how plain and forgettable they seemed. Even the names for most are very uninspiring. But I mean I get it, making cool monster designs is a specialized skill, let alone naming them. I think they invested a lot in the gameplay and it really paid off. The learning curve for the battle system and the skills the game has is pretty steep in my opinion. There aren't a lot of elements for the weak vs strong mechanic, but there are different buffs, debuffs, passives involving both, critical and non-critical damage, neutral damage, etc.

Monster Sanctuary is a mix of a Metroidvania and a JRPG (a JRPG very inspired by Pokémon) that shows how much a few twists can make and old formula feel great.

I'll start with the most interesting and enjoyable feature of the game: the monster battle. The game, as I said before, feels inspired by Pokémon but I think it goes the extra mile and it isn't a "copy & paste". The first thing you will notice is that all the battles you use 3 monsters, this makes SO much sense because this allows the player to build a party that have sinergy and each mon can play a different role in the combat. This is the reason why Pokémon tournaments are 2v2 and not just 1v1 where you almost always avoid support or tank abilities in favor a damage ones. So... having 3 mons allows you to build a team, with different roles, but that its just half of the combat, the other half are the skills. The skills system is complex enough to make you feel that you are choosing how you want to build each mon, but it is simple to understand what each skill will do and how it will combine with each other. Each monster have between 3 and 5 skill tree to allocate points with different focuses (magic damage, physical damage, healing, shielding, buffing, debuffing, aoe, single target, etc etc etc).

Ok, so I've discussed how the "JRPG part is" but how about the Metroidvania or the story? First lets talk about the exploration and platforming part. This part is really straight foward, playing you will face obstacles where you will need to acquire one of two things: a new power up for the character (as double jumping) OR a new mon that has an explore ability that you need (flying, swimming, mounting, etc.). The latter is what I think makes this game excel without making a game changing innovation in the classic metroidvania formula, it just let you choose (and see in action) what monster of your collection you want to help you and in what scenario, I think that this makes so much sense and makes you feel more engage on the game.

Finally, the story. I must say that it isn't a story that shake my world and will keep it in my mind forever. It's simple, but it fulfills it's role to push you through the game.

I want to give a shout out to the art style that, although being simple, it's beautiful. I love pixel art. 
PSA: If you want to have a full image of the monster, remember to go to the monster journal.

100% Recommended. You like Metroidvania? Go for it. You like Pokémon-like games? Go for it.
Also... it's a freaking perfect game to play via steam link on your phone.

This is one of my favorite games of all time. that being said there are pros and cons.

     This game is very balanced. I got to be part of the beta test, and the developers are very open to feedback and balancing changed recommended by the community. There are countless hours of debates and discussions about the balance. Especially for the upcoming DLC, there are no monsters that are unusable, and every individual monster or team has counter play.
     The amount of things you can do when building a team or an individual monster is nuts. So many monsters can fit so many roles with so many different types of teams, even I with almost 800 hours haven't tried all the different types of teams you can build.
     I actually think the difficulty in this game is a pro. After adding a casual mode, there should be no more complaints about it being too hard. Also there's many ways to make the game more difficult, even on top of just increasing the difficulty.
     The art and music for the game are great. I know something like music and art are pretty subjective, but i personally like the art and music quite a bit. 

Cons
     If someone were to want to try PVP, they would run into a couple of roadblocks. The stars would have to align for someone to find a match in queue. not only that, but they would most likely get stomped. The only way to avoid this is though the discord, where you can find consistent matches to play and are able to discuss plenty about what you teams lacks and why you lost.
     The early game is difficult for 2 reasons. 1, tutorials and dialogue in general is easily skipped and new players could easily get lost. 2, it can be very complicated to learn and understand everything at the start, and some battles at the start can be hard without either a good bit of time or someone you help you.
     I'm a but hesitant to put the story as a con, because I think the story is alright. There were some nice twists and a satisfying ending, but I can see arguments for it being boring.


Overall, I think that the cons are few and avoidable, and with this i cant stress enough how great the discord is for this game. The community is fantastic and super helpful, theres regular tournaments put on with people casting it and everything. 

TLDR

very balanced.
nice art and music.
can be hard to start because its complicated
Amazing discord and community

Holy cow... I cant really concisely articulate just how incredible this game is.  This review is intended to be relatively comprehensive but I may miss a few things, and it is probably going to end up being a tad lengthy so please bare with me.

Pokemon, Metroid and Castlevania are all very important games that pioneered their genres, popularized them and helped to shape many modern games today . All 3 of these IPs have games that are considered so good that they are masterpieces that transcend time and can be enjoyed again and again regardless of age by incredibly large numbers of people.  Pokemon specifically is one of, if not the most valuable video game IP on the planet proving that the monster taming genre appeals to incredibly large numbers of people worldwide.  

All that, and yet, Monster Sanctuary has managed to eclipse Pokemon entirely in it's first entry, by taking the genre to the next level. This game takes everything you love about the best Pokemon games in that series and combines it with the main design elements that are core to the metroidvania genre. This fusion is, frankly, ingenious, and pulled off seamlessly.   Monster Sanctuary doesn't stop there though! 

The monsters themselves are elevated above and beyond anything Pokemon has managed by giving them each multiple skill trees and monster  equipment, allowing you to build them in specific ways. Because of this, there is a huge emphasis on team building and strategy.  The strategy and team building elements are balanced to utter perfection. Every  single monster in the game is strong and viable. All the while, no one monster or strategy is without weakness so there is no "best strategy" or "best monster".  The shifting system (dark and light monsters) adds another layer of depth and complexity to the team building. Some monsters even evolve which alter their skill trees entirely. 

Monster sanctuary can be quite challenging at times, but never manages to feel unfair, or oppressive. These challenges encourage you to rethink your team and strategy and make diving deeper into the team building, skill trees, equipment and shifting systems in order to problem solve fun, rewarding, and addictive. 

You can collect as many monsters as you want, and can choose one that will follow you on screen (swapping between them is simple and without restriction). Each of these monsters has abilities that will aid you in a variety of ways.  The level design is masterfully done (as it should be in any metroidvania game), encouraging you to go back to areas you could not fully explore before later on and rewarding you for doing so. There are plenty of secrets to look for and puzzles to solve (requiring varying degrees of brain power) The soundtrack is fantastic. Movement feels great.  The platforming has points where it might take a few attempts  to overcome, but doesn't ever feel unfair, or frustrating.  The story is fine. Simple, but well told, with plenty of room for expansion in future games.  The environments, graphics and animations are all beautifully done.  Multiplayer PvP is supported as well. 

In closing I will say this: Monster Sanctuary is, without question, the strongest game in the monster taming genre  I have ever played and is one hell of a good metroidvania game too. It is one of the absolute greatest games that I have ever played, period.  I feel confident recommending this to absolutely everyone.  Buy it, support the game, and the developers so that we can hopefully get more Monster Sanctuary games in the future. I can think of no game more worthy of mass support than this one.

I don't leave many reviews, but this game is just excellent. There are 111 creatures each with dozens of skills, each has multiple slots for various items that can have effects pretty similar to skills yet doing different things, and each monster has multiple forms adding a special passive, and all of it comes down to a wide variety of effects, builds, and synergies, somehow balanced enough that basically any of these monsters are viable and reasonably balanced.

One thing to note, this isn't pokemon. Battles are longer, extremely different, you aren't limited to 4 different moves to choose from, and there is a heavy focus on synergies, team building, and strategy. Also a lot of long term planning.

The story itself isn't overly complicated, but I like it. It provides plenty of motives and reasons to fuel your journey, it has some mysteries both revealed and hidden as the story progresses, it makes sense, and it creates a nice sense of bitter-sweetness near the end. For elaboration on that, [spoiler] you achieve your goal, there is enough to feel like your side was in the right, but you can also understand the reasons for the other side's actions, and it is hard to hate or even fully disagree with them. It is the end to the story, but feels like true change and more stories still await.[/spoiler]

Overall, I would call it a great game, a bit of a hidden gem, but I am going to make a list of pros and cons anyways.

Pros:
*Good and atmospheric music
*Excellent long-term planning if that is something you are fond of
*Surprisingly well balanced
*There is a very wide variety of potential builds that are all viable
*Does a good job at introducing new mechanics or expanding on previous ones at good intervals that maintain a relatively constant set of progression
*Nice lore and world-building
*Pretty open, after the first couple of areas, things branch out pretty quickly and there are a lot of areas you can potentially go to. Even after you have completed an area, there are often different sections of it you can't initially access, and plenty of reasons to come back later.
*Even though it was already a complete game, recently a new free DLC was added adding a lot of content. Pretty great so far.

Cons:
*There are a lot of fights, and it can start feeling a bit tedious at some points
*There are maybe 2-3 songs used for battles, only one for normal fights. This makes battle music somewhat disappointing compared to the various area themes.
* From what I have heard, can have a fairly steep learning curve for a new player, though someone with some experience in these sorts of games can get a handle of things pretty quickly
*If you don't like team-building and trying to build synergies, it is a pretty major part of the game.
*Limited post-game at the moment. There are some pretty fun and challenging battles to complete, some final monsters to hunt down to complete your bestiary, options to re-battle some of the game's equivalent to bosses, a pretty good new game plus with a higher difficulty mode (which in a game like this, is less just beefing up stats, and more increasing the number of options, tools, and synergies available to enemies), but besides that it is mostly just challenges you make yourself.

Overall, I would say it is one of the better games I have played in quite a while, and I had to spend a fair amount of time thinking to fill out that con list some more, as opposed to the pro list where I had little trouble thinking of new things to add. I would definitely recommend it for it's price tag, and especially if you can get it on sale. It beats out the vast majority of other $20 games you will find even without a sale though, and the free DLC coming up is probably only going to make it even better.

EDIT: New free DLC arrived. Adds a lot of really fun monsters, an interesting new area with nice music, some fun fights, added some fun new skills and exploration abilities, the new modes are great, and so on. Plus, with the arrival of the new skills, they also went back and made adjustments to every monster in the game. Overall feels like it helped improve the balance even further and gave some fun new things to play with.

116449897.review:
Monster Sanctuary is a game that could have easily gotten a positive review from me if it had been balanced a bit better, and if any attention whatsoever had been given to the stability of the game's difficulty. I was originally hesitant to buy because it looked too casual for me, and I wanted a challenge. And it is too easy. Far too easy. And then, without warning, too hard to bother with.

In Monster Sanctuary, you encounter two types of enemy teams. The vast majority are [i]contemptibly[/i] easy, even on "Master" difficulty. But periodically, and especially in the late game, the long yawn-inducing stretches of easy enemies are punctuated by enemies you will [i]not[/i] beat without assistance. Not unless you have a serious devotion to the game that I will never have.

There are over a hundred monsters to recruit, and you can make a team that gets you to the endgame using any you like, provided they're basically suited for the current situation. Use fire monsters against monsters weak to fire, for example. Or take more healing and debuff removal against poison monsters.

However, getting through the content in this game is not thriving. The game pushes you hard to extreme min-maxing, punishing you heavily with fewer drops and monster recruits if you don't conduct your fights [i]just so[/i]. It doesn't matter if you win. You have to win quickly by exploiting weaknesses and by performing everything in the order they think you should. You can 1-shot the entire enemy team (I have done this) with the wrong damage type, and your performance will be rated subpar.

But no matter how carefully you perform the dance steps, the vast majority of monsters are utterly useless in the late game, particularly in the last half dozen fights or so. Of around 100 monsters, I got significant use out of fewer than 10, and most weren't even worth trying once. 

You have two options if you want to complete the game. You can go watch YouTube videos that show you exactly the magic combination of monsters that will work, or you can devote yourself utterly to min-maxing and trial and error to see what apparently good combos actually work.

You can easily spend the same amount of time on the last 5% of the game as you did on the previous 95%, purely in grinding out levels so that you can test yet another combination on the endgame encounters. But I'm not into grinding. I do not enjoy going through 30-40 boring, easy combats to level a monster up to endgame status, upgrade its equipment, and find the consumables that add the final, essential abilities. But I do this so I can find out that the combo I envisioned isn't going to work. And I've done it at least a dozen times now, so my patience is at an end.

If this were a Souls-like, I could just practice and get better, memorize the fights, and use the high skill cap to my advantage. But here, it's about grinding out levels and items simply for another chance to throw spaghetti at the wall.

Perhaps if the end of the game simply allowed you to use every monster at max level, and all available variants and equipment, this would be OK. But grind is never OK. I have things to attend to.

If you need evidence that this game turns into a pointless slog, just look at the global achievements. Over 90% of players haven't bothered to finish the game. 

I've abandoned Monster Sanctuary at the penultimate battle, and while it might have otherwise been a good game, it has greatly overstayed its welcome, and I'm glad to see the back of it. And that is not the sign of a good game.

100+ critters await you here, and building a team of 6 is your challenge. Lots of variety in designs, plenty of builds possible per critter, and getting those synergies on your team going is quite nice. Interesting to see more of the map as you get new critter powers as well.

116107768.review:
I bought this game on a whim (because it was on a sale, not because I was very interested in it) and I was VERY pleasantly surprised by it. This was not what I had expected at all. Just look at my playtime with this title. I even unlocked all the Steam achievements (which is actually doable here)!

Monster Sanctuary is both a puzzle platformer and a turn-based combat strategy game. It also has a bit of a backstory which I thought was nice, cozy and - due to the bad guy characters and their motivations - also fit for an older audience.

The real meat of the game is of course the combat aspect. There are around a hundred different monsters for you to collect. A few can be evolved into different forms (rather simplistic though, you just need a special item). Each monster can also be of a light or dark variant. These variants change the coloration scheme of the monster and give it a strong special passive ability. Which turns your 100 monsters more or less into 200 monsters.

The monsters have a fixed stats growth and each has a specific skill tree where you can allocate a skill point for every gained level (40 is the max level). You can reset the skill tree at any time with a very common item. This also applies on a larger scale. Any monster can always be readjusted if you so desire (light to dark, etc.).

Some monsters are very rare (meaning you only get 1 per playthrough unless you get lucky with reward boxes). The same also applies to special equipment items. Speaking of equipment, each item can be upgraded to +5 which greatly enhances its stats.

And so on and so forth. Developing your monsters and teaming them up together to fighting other monster groups (or champions) is quite complex and opens up a huge amount of possible combinations. You can spend a lot of time here and this is one of the things that make Monster Sanctuary so much fun.

But the puzzles, the map secrets, the story and the minigames (like the infinity arena) make the game even better! After finishing the game you can even start over with a new game+ and keep all your current monsters (with a few special rules though). And that's actually a pretty great way to experience the game again with a fresh monster team.

There is so much more to say but I'll leave it at that. This is a really great title where I'm pretty sure that the developer actually enjoyed what he was doing because everything is thought out very well and just feels right. Strongly recommended from my side!

115940342.review:
TLDR: I 100%'d it, and I wish I could play more. A superb 3v3 monster raising game with a good metroidvania tacked on for traversal. Fully recommend, hope they make a sequel.

The best way to summarize Monster Sanctuary is to break it into its component parts. It is important to note though, every part of this game is well done. The story you can take or leave, its serviceable, but the amount of love and care put into descriptions of the monsters is enough to make up for it.

Metroidvania: The traversal mechanics are simple enough, with the uniqueness of most of your actual unlocks are monsters themselves. Sometimes this does mean you need to get a monster ability to progress, and that requires a few fights, but this is minimal. You do get a double jump, but most of the standard new mechanics are monster based. A monster will break walls, allow a glide, swim, burn vines, etc. The only negative here is I wish you could mark areas, as when finishing things up I would forget where the new ability I got could be used in older areas.

Monster Raising: Every monster has a skill tree. It isn't fully unique, a lot of skills are shared between monsters, but the exact layout and amount of abilities differs. There is enough difference and a hard cap on skill points that you could ostensibly build two monsters of the same type differently. In addition, there is gear, some with unique bonuses other than stats, and a later mechanic introduces a choice of two unique bonus options. Some of these are -major- and you build a team around them (Bleed stacks not going away for example, letting you stack up hundreds to slowly murder a defensive monster). Further in addition, if you make a mistake in a build, or want to change things out, there are items to reset skills, level up lower monsters and the like. I never felt like a bad choice locked me out of any potentials, and I could easily reconfigure my team. Lastly, every monster gets 1 of 3 unique 'ultimate' skills, which you can change between fights without an item. All of this adds up to a superb experience making unique teams and trying out new combinations.

Combat: The 3v3 style, along with the raising detailed above, means that you have a lot of opportunity for fun combat challenges. Some fights will be against one huge monster that acts multiple times, but often you will be facing a team of three. If it is an opponent trainer, you will 6v6, with three out at a time. Buffs and debuffs are very important, and some monsters are entirely built around healing when buffing, getting free buffs, spreading debuffs, super-stacking them, etc. You also heal to full after every fight, but there is a grading system based on buff/debuffs, rounds taken, damage, how 'efficient' you are that makes you want to do every fight well. The higher the grade, the better chance of getting rare items (including eggs for monsters to raise).

In summary, an amazing game, fully worth 100%'ng, and doesn't deserve to be compared to Pokemon. Its better.

A 3 person party metroidvania rpg where every monster you obtain has its own unique skill tree.  I had tons of fun figuring out how to combo together unique monster abilities.  A lot of people compare this to Pokemon, but the battle system in this game is so much more detailed and in depth than Pokemon that its not even fair.

Battling random monsters in the world is typically super easy, but other monster trainers frequently present difficulty spikes that have you reconsidering your party composition.

Hatching new monsters always puts them near your party's max level so you never really have to grind out levels.  If any monster you want to use falls behind in levels the game also gives you plenty of level-up badges to boost them up.  If you ever want to re-roll your monsters skill tree you also get tons of free skill-resets.  I never felt like I had to grind out levels or wade through tons of repetitive battles like I did in other similar games.

PS.  You can speed up the battle animations in the settings, which helps keep battles feeling snappy and quick.

With the 'singleplayer', 'turn-based tactics' and 'creature collector' tags, it's impossible not to think of this game as faux-pokemon but it couldn't be more unique!
The similar qualities listed are the only similarities there are because apart from that, Monster Sanctuary differentiates itself in every other way:
- Most notably, it almost perfectly assimilates the creature-collecting and platforming metroidvania genres, with me eagerly going back to previous areas I couldn't pass as soon as I unlock a new ability
- It is largely open world with the player being able to explore areas in largely any order they want, whether that is by following quests across the map or simply exploring, with the enemy levels scaling to the amount of the map explored when you encounter them, leading to a lack of grind but certainly not a complete lack of challenge
- The combat system is also a fresh take with the player controlling 3 monsters at one time so synergy is heavily encouraged and team combinations are endless so coming up with overpowered synergies is endlessly fun

The only drawbacks I'd say the game has are that I can see how it wouldn't be too appealing to the type of players are aren't fans of the creature-collecting or metroidvania genres and actively avoid them but if you've taken any interest at all in these genres then I'd greatly encourage you to give Monster Sanctuary a try, because, above all, it is simply a breath of fresh air.

Just from the store page I probably wouldn't have looked at this game twice, and how very wrong I would be to do so. I was given this game as a birthday present, and I have been completely engrossed by it. Monster Sanctuary is a wholesome pet battler game with Metroid-style world exploration, and yet it does some things so well that I earnestly believe Pokemon could learn a thing or two from it. Each pet has a Warcraft-style talent tree, allowing for the same pet to be built in many different ways. There are no IVs/EVs, but your talent choices are what differentiate your crab from a friend's. This variety in how each pet can be built combined with the 3v3 format allows for near-infinite combinations of pets, and rewards you for getting creative with your team builds. I have had heaps of fun in my latest playthrough doing an Aquatic-only theme for example.

If you enjoy Pokemon games or had a childhood of Digimon World 2003, this game gets my strongest possible recommendation.

Huckleberry pancakes.

1 3/4 cups all purpose white flour
4 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 cups of buttermilk
5 tablespoon butter, melted
2 large eggs
1/2 cup Huckleberries
In medium bowl combine flour, sugar, baking powder and salt, set aside. In small bowl combine buttermilk, butter and eggs. Add buttermilk mixture to the flour mixture, combine until mixed do not over mix (I prefer to use a whisk it does the best job). Fry at 400 degrees. Pour about 1/4 cup of batter on the griddle and sprinkle with the huckleberries.

Cook on first side about 3 minutes until bubbles appear along the edge of the pancake. Flip and cook for 2 minutes more and golden brown. Serve with a big pat of butter, and some pure maple syrup ( get the real stuff it is worth it).

Monster Sanctuary: a platforming, monster collecting game, with some fun puzzles along the way.
After having played through the entire game and almost 5* every champion, here are my thoughts on the game. I will note that I am pretty casual about how I've played and have not done ANY online dueling.
[h1]
What I enjoyed about this game:
[/h1]
[list]
[*] Each monster has its own unique skill tree. This includes evolved monsters as they have completely different skills trees from their predecessors. Also, resetting skill trees was easy as it only cost a handful of money to buy a skill reset item and monsters seemed to semi-frequently drop them in the late game.
[*] Skill trees were expansive and varying enough to where most monsters felt like they had multiple viable paths depending on what you wanted them to do. (Do I want monster X to be a tanky shielder/healer or a debuff/buffer? Maybe a mediocre mix of both?)
[*] I felt that being able to shift monsters added a neat layer of added bonuses to double down on whatever decisions you made in the skill tree.
[*] Puzzles and platforming were simple enough to where it never felt like it was impossible but varying enough to be enjoyable.
[*] Storyline was enjoyable even if you could see a few things coming. I hope there's a sequel where you get to go to the main "other" place mentioned.
[/list]

[h1]
What I felt could be better/minor improvement suggestions:
[/h1]
[list]
[*] This is probably due to my lack of experience with metroidvanias, but certain obstacles can only be overcome with certain monster skills (not a problem). But sometimes you'll run into these obstacles early on and not get the respective monster until much later in the game (also not a problem). However, there is no way to mark the map or to tell where these areas were, aside from the noticeable dead-ends where there is clearly a door or partially explored region. So a lot of my time was spent backtracking through areas to be like.. "Where could I use this monster again????" and checking every map dead end or area where I thought I saw a treasure chest. This could be easily solved with a map marker for things like "Big X Thing here". But again, this might be part of the fun for some people, just not for me.
[*] I wish there were more evolutions! This isn't so much a negative as something that could definitely be expanded upon, because honestly I love most of the evolutions that already do exist. Evolutions felt so cool and meaningful because you get an entirely new skill tree. But, unlike something like Pokemon where seemingly every pokemon can evolve, it only felt like a very select subset of monsters could actually evolve, though I'm sure this is also limited by the length of the game. Also you mostly (to my memory) only get the items necessary to evolve them once you've already encountered their evolved form, so there isn't very much surprise to it on what the monster will evolve into when you get an evolution item.
[/list]

Honestly I don't have a lot bad to say about the game. I found it pretty enjoyable for what it was. Some people were saying that you have to farm a lot but I never had to farm throughout the game and could just use level badges (gives +1 level like rare candy) whenever I needed to get a couple levels. The hardest part for me was just getting 5* on the main bosses because I'm not super creative when it comes to team comps and I didn't want to look anything up.

An amazing game. It took me a few hours to get into because it was too easy at first. My biggest problem with pokemon and why i can't enjoy it is because it's mind-numbingly easy. Don't be deceived by how it looks. This game has plenty of depth to it. Your strategy and team synergy is very important in this game. It makes you always think about your team makeup and how to improve it because you're constantly being challenged. Another bonus here is don't be afraid to change your monsters out or change the allocation of the skill points on them. The game makes it very easy to make these kind of changes so you can always try new things. i myself had three different team setups i would switch out depending on who/what i was fighting. 

If i had to nitpick on anything i would say some puzzles were kind of annoying. I understand this game wanted to add metroidvania style gameplay and stuff but i thought that stuff was the weaker part of this game. I thoroughly enjoyed combat, but was annoyed when i ran into these brick walls of puzzles where i had to focus on doing that for 10-15 minutes. They're not long, but some puzzles seemed overly complex. I personally did not enjoy them because i was eager to get back to the combat and i'm not a huge fan of metroidvania mechanics anyway. You guys might differ here. 

Another nitpick might be that i feel the base game is a little short. It just seemed like as my teams finally came together and my understanding of the game got to a good point, it was over. I'm not a huge fan of new game plus in general. Having said that there's plenty of replayability here. Going through new game plus doesn't sound completely terrible to me with this kind of game since you can try out new monsters and make new teams. Overall, It's definitely worth a buy. This is a great game that's definitely worth your time. If you like pokemon, but want something different, maybe a bit more challenging, this is for you.

This isn't a bad game in terms of Metroidvania.  The abilities you get are pretty bland, such as [spoiler]double jump, hover, morph ball, swim..[/spoiler].  It's sort of a mix of Metroidvania and Pokemon in a sense.  When you encounter enemies, you go into an RPG-style monster battle.  Sometimes wild monsters drop an egg item you can use to get that monster.  Each monster has its own level, strengths and weaknesses, various attack types, and a semi-unique skill tree.  As you progress through different areas, you have to figure out what monsters to put in your party that are strong against the monsters found in that area.

The story isn't half bad and has a fair amount of dialog, although plot twists are few.

The game does have some good quality of life features.  For example, when a monster is max level, you continue to "level up" with that monster.  Each time you fill the exp bar again, you instead get an item that allows you to give that level to a different monster, so you aren't throwing exp in the garbage by using your best monsters.  It would be a shame to feel like you were wasting exp by using them right after they [spoiler]unlock their ultimate at max level[/spoiler].

One sharp criticism I do have of the game is that the difficulty curve turns into a rather sharp spike with "RNG" written on it.  Up until you get to that point, the difficulty is pretty mild.  48 hours in and nearly at the end, I called it out of frustration from losing constantly.  I decided to go back and give it another try because I really hate to lave a game unfinished like that, and guess what?  RNG is a fickle thing.  I blasted through the last several bosses with the same party I was already using without losing once.  It does have a difficulty setting you can adjust, but the RNG toward the end is lethal on any setting.

All in all, I enjoyed the game except for getting frustrated with the RNG near the end.

This is more of a RPG with a light sprinkling of exploration than a true Metroidvania. As long as you capture monsters as you meet them, you will generally have all the tools you need to explore the majority of an area when you first come accross it, except in the beginning of the game, and at a couple points in the story - where you will promptly be directed toward the ability that will allow you to progress. And if you can't reach a chest, well, it's not really a big deal - the vast majority of chests contain items that you can easily acquire from merchants, or that are dropped from monsters, or sometimes their content is literally random (well, technically you get a fixed item, that you then use to get a random reward). So unless your goal is to get the 100% map achievement, if you miss something... It's not a big deal.

There are a bunch of monsters, and all of them are viable, even the ones you encounter early. The good thing about that is that you can compose an end-game worthy team in the first few areas. The bad thing is that it kinda saps the feeling of progression. Like, okay, I went into the hidden magma caves and got a badass fire breathing dragon... but why should I care when the random goblin I got ages ago is just as good, if not better? This is even the case for evolved monsters. Some monsters can evolve, but their evolved form isn't going to be strictly better - just different. And the game outright tells you as much. In particular there's a late game opponent who has both the base and evolved form of a monster in their team, and the unevolved one is by far the greater threat of the two. It's a bit jarring.

The meat and potato of the game is the combat. And it's pretty good. There are plenty of strategies available and things to consider. One thing to note though, this isn't like Pokemon where you can just take your favorite looking monsters and smash your head into the wall until the wall gives. The difficulty is scaled in a way that a team that doesn't synergise is doomed to fail. That said, there is literally no penalty for failure. If you lose a fight, you're just put back in front of it, ready to try again immediately or turn back and change stuff. There are only a couple of fight where losing simply denies you an extra reward, but those rewards are literally random, so it's not exactly a huge loss.

All in all, I recommend the game. Good times.

An approachable metroidvania turn-based monster collector with sufficiently complex party composition choices to be interesting. The story is a bit cliche, but inoffensively so - I've seen far worse writing in much bigger budget titles.

Battle system is interesting, intuitive, and approachable - with a surprising amount of depth. Fights can get very repetitive after a while, since the majority of battles (even trash fights against things 1/4 your level when you're going back through an old area) wind up being 3v3's that can sometimes take 2 or 3 rounds to complete. This is mitigated somewhat by a map traversal power that lets you avoid encounters.

Exploration is good, the map does not have to be completed in a linear order, and enemies scale based on how much you have explored, so you shouldn't ever really get too far out of your depth no matter which route you take.

Completed in ~28 hours with 100% map completion and most (but not all of the pokedex).

My only real complaint (apart from not being able to completely ignore trash fights when backtracking and thus making the long fights feel longer than they need to be) is the user interface. It has enough console platformer in its genes to make things *just* a bit clunkier than necessary when played on a PC. There never seems to be quite enough information on the screen, which makes inventory management, level advancement, and party organization take longer than they should.

[i]Truncated due to character limits. Full review at [url=http://www.dragon-quill.net/monster-sanctuary/]Dragon Quill.[/url] Comments are enabled there.[/i]

Monster Sanctuary is a cross between a monster catcher RPG and a Metroidvania. I am interested in both of those things, so I decided to check it out.

This game is better than Pokemon in every conceivable way except for the most important one: Monster designs. As you can see in the banner above, monster designs are incredibly basic, usually consisting of real plants, animals, or mythical creatures with only minor twists. And those tiny overworld sprites are all you’re getting; you don’t get to see detailed closeups in battle like you do in Pokemon. This is highly unfortunate, because the game is otherwise very enjoyable and has a number of features I wish Pokemon would include.

The game’s big claim to fame is that every single monster has a skill that helps you explore the world in addition to their battle skills, a little like HMs from Pokemon but placed much more center stage. This is what makes the game a Metroidvania: instead of gating progress through items or upgrades to your character, you need to find monsters with the right skill to reach new areas or optional goodies. Not every monster has a unique exploration skill, but this still added a lot of personality to them and helped them feel like real creatures instead of just battle-bots.

The other cool thing is that battles require more than one iota of thought. All battles are 3v3 rather than 1v1, all enemy trainers have a full team, and monsters can survive more than two hits. This means that status and support moves actually matter, and are in fact a cornerstone of most advanced strategies. Additionally, instead of learning new moves automatically on level up, every monster has a skill tree that you can customize yourself, which makes me feel a lot more involved in their development and allows for even more tactical depth. This added complexity means that every monster actually feels like it has a unique niche, rather than them being interchangeable outside of elemental coverage like in Pokemon.

Another thing the game does is that your monsters can have equipment (one weapon and three accessories), which I’m ambivalent about. It provides more opportunities for customization, yes, but for me it felt like too much micromanagement for a game with 101 potential party members. It’s pretty grindy, too, because in order to improve equipment you need to gather crafting materials, which drop randomly from enemies, making it a crapshoot if you’ll get the ones you need. Also, weirdly, every monster starts with a basic weapon that is necessary to boost their attack stats to a meaningful level but for some reason can be unequipped. I feel like, given this is a game about monsters, not humans, they should be relying more on their innate skills than equipment modifiers. Pokemon’s single held items that provided small qualitative changes were enough complexity, this is too much.

This ties into my more substantial criticism, which is that the game overall feels much too complex. So much of the stuff that happens in battles happens automatically; it’s all effects that trigger follow-up effects that trigger follow-up effects that trigger follow-up effects. Good builds require you to exploit these several layers deep, so that every action you take heals you, which grants you a buff, which lets you do a follow-up attack, which… Every single turn in this game features a truly dizzying amount of things happening beyond the action you just took, with no indication of what triggered what or exactly what happened. Playing this game for too long literally gives me a headache, and it’s not hard to see why.

This is especially bad when encountering new enemies; while you can guess what’s going on with your monsters since you built them, you have no idea why this new monster just oneshotted your tank and fully healed itself on the same turn, and thus you have no idea what you’re supposed to do in response.

One thing I did like is that instead of learning new abilities automatically, monsters have skill trees that you invest points in every time they level up. You can never max out a tree (as the level cap is scaled for you to hit at the end of the game instead of off in space), requiring you to make actual choices and come up with customized builds. Monsters can end up remarkably different if you diversify their tree or go all in on one branch, and depending on what passives you choose. This made me feel much more involved and invested in my monsters’ development than I ever did in Pokemon, and lends more credence to the idea you are actually training them. It’s definitely something more mons games should consider.

However, despite all of this complicated setup, the game forces you to rely a lot on random chance. In addition to critical hits, there are buffs and debuffs that can make you randomly miss attacks, and there are a ton of abilities and items that provide a buff or debuff that’s chosen randomly. This isn’t too bad, because a core mechanic is that all of your attacks hit multiple times, so random effects get averaged out… Except, as you might notice in the above video, there’s a scoring system that ranks you on how well the battle went, with crucial rewards like new monsters gated behind high scores. This is immensely frustrating if you’re just on the cusp of getting a perfect score, because you don’t know if that means you need to change your strategy or if you just got unlucky. You can fight a battle the exact same way and get different results, which is fine in general but not if you’re turning battles into a puzzle that must be performed perfectly. And, again, this isn’t just for bragging rights; getting new monsters, the game’s core feature, requires getting high scores.

Compounding this is that the leveling curve is incredibly punishing. See, unlike in Pokemon, boss battles are hair-pullingly difficult, with every enemy trainer having a full and well-balanced team that’s deliberately scaled to be higher level than you. It’s impossible to coast through the game with a single team, as you’ll need to switch out most or all of your monsters for every boss to come up with a viable counter. However, like in Pokemon, benched mons gain no experience from battles; so even if you know intellectually what monsters you should swap for, they’ll be statistically useless until you do a ton of grinding first. This was incredibly frustrating and unfun, and completely killed the pacing every time I ran into a brick wall of a boss. Pokemon also has this problem (which is why people who complain about the EXP share and EXP candies are nuts), we just don’t notice because it’s so easy a monkey can play it.

The game does throw you one bone with Rare Candy-type items that give monsters free levels (capped by the level of your strongest monster, which I thought was a good throttle)… except they’re limited items, so you can only use them to bring one or two old monsters up to par, out of dozens of options. Bizarrely, a late-game area has a shop that lets you buy unlimited amounts for a pittance, which just makes me ask why we couldn’t have that from the start.

Despite my gripes, I’m still putting this down as a rec. It’s a fun game overall, and it’s good to experience different takes on the mons genre. Like I said, it’s better than Pokemon in nearly every way, so I don’t object to spreading it around.

While finishing the story did leave me feeling a bit confined in the Sanctuary (I want more), it was all because the game did such a great job of giving me such a rich experience within the confines of the world that I was given to explore and the monsters I was able to hatch. I love that you can't just power through all the content with the same team (without experiencing diminishing returns). Combos and team roles (healer/shield/damage/etc) are a thing and slowly become a wall you need to overcome in order to learn how to efficiently win battles without simply using brute force (until you figure out a team that can use said force efficiently).

I love that in this game, equipment and food buffs are an actual thing to signify progression instead of just being tacked on. I also experienced a lot of freedom in swapping around monsters for my various teams as I worked my way through the post-game content. The game allows you to invest resources, within reason, towards new monsters so that you can try out various builds without experiencing buyer's remorse. It's a game that wants you to try everything and really think about various builds within each extensive skill tree to make the most of your experience.

It was just an awesome experience overall and Monster Sanctuary definitely filled a void created by my disappointment in newer Pokémon games. I'm glad that this game was one of the few I chose to pick up again after a long hiatus from Steam. Money well spent!

Going to start with the TL;DR and then go into the details.

TL;DR this game is amazing if you want a turn based game with heavy theorycrafting and low grind investment needed. If you were intrigued by the buzzword Metroidvania, be aware that there aren't really any platforming challenges and the ones that are there are pretty simple- similarly combat in this game is if you touch a monster your JRPG combat begins.

So with that out of the way, this game is amazing if you like theorycrafting. Combat works like a standard party JRPG (not really pokemon), you get 3 monsters to battle against the enemy 3 monsters, each side takes all their actions at once. But the awesome part is there's over 100 monsters in this game, each with a branching skill tree, and ALL of them are good enough to include in a team. Some are more generically strong, but almost everything can atleast be niche viable- including unevolved monsters (TBH there's only a handful of evolutions, but evolutions in this game are sidegrades and have tradeoffs) So basically there are a lot of pieces to imagine team compositions around.

The story mode itself has a standard forgettable kid friendly plot line common in monster collecting games, but the difficulty is decently well scaled, with wild battles being able to wreck you if you just mishmashed some mons, with some bosses being able to dismantle some compositions. But toward the end it does have some pretty challenging fights that do require you to bring a well rounded team and may require you to adjust if your team isn't working.

So now lets talk grinding. As far as XP, the game doesn't really require any excess during the initial playthrough, just fighting the standard amount of encounters thrown at you while exploring the map will keep you where expected. Adding new monsters is easy- depending on your level monsters when caught will always be 2-5 levels behind your highest level monster- and your "rare candies" in this game get handed out like, well, candy- so the only difficult part can be catching them, as admittedly if you don't overlevel them you may need to swap around your comp to be able to even catch particular monsters as your chance of catching a new monster is based off of doing a fight "well" which if your team is well constructed then it usually shouldn't be an issue. The game does have its "shines", and they are actually important, essentially being the actual "evolved" forms of the monsters offering an strong passive and extra stats- but that said the chance of one spawning when hunting is about 1/12, and the playthrough will hand you about 10 items that let you upgrade a monster to the "shiny" status anyway.

So now lets just round out with "what can I do with all this theorycrafting?" well a couple things, besides finishing the playthrough, the game does offer PvP, which while the game is not super popular you can expect to atleast match with people. It has an infinite arena mode, so you can try to see how many rounds your team can go against increasing modifiers, and finally new game+ (which does give the option to be done on a seperate save or the same one) which lets you do a new playthrough with ALL of your monsters you caught the first time, but reset to level 1 against enemies scaled higher than the initial playthrough, letting you reexperience the game with comps you wouldn't have been able to access until you were already 3/4s done the first time.

As a guy who loves TCGs and Monster catchers for the vast theorycrafting, this game has quickly become one of my favorite indie games I've played in the last few years. I will reiterate one last time, If you like theorycrafting too I would highly recommend picking this up.

This is such an unexpectedly charming and engaging experience, and genuinely my favorite creature-catcher game to date. Cozy spritework and music, with a heavy focus on teambuilding. The combat is fantastic - it's a 3-on-3 active party system that rewards things like buffs, debuffs and multihit attacks. I felt like the way it wants you to think more heavily about the way your party works for you reminded me positively of the Shin Megami Tensei series. You have a lot of different options and ways to make your monsters work for you, and the game loves to reward you for building effective teams with many different roles. As someone who was disillusioned with the battle mechanics and lack of challenge of a game like Pokemon, this really satisfied me - this isn't a diss at Pokemon so much as me painting a picture of the kind of game this is and who it will appeal to.

The amount of monsters comes a little over 100, but this is far from an issue, as each one is distinct, with their own unique customizable skilltrees, and from my experience not a single one has ever felt like they were dead weight. The maps are fixed, but it's fine because they're well-designed, fun, and encourage backtracking in an organic and interesting way. At times I could see it being too challenging for some people, but I personally loved how difficult it could be at times. The story isn't anything special, but it really captures this simple and cute 2000s kid hero game feel. I spotted a few grammatical oddities but if anything that kind of added to that "secret hidden gem I found used at Gamestop for my DS" vibe.

Aside from the main game being a meaty enough experience that you'll spend tons of time exploring, playing with team ideas, and battling, the game offers many diversions. After beating the game, there's a New Game Plus mode and a higher difficulty, as well as postgame challenges in the form of an endless arena and a special hall to fight harder monster teams. A recent free update even added features for Randomizer runs, Nuzlockes, and a whole new postgame region with more monsters and battles. I love to come back to it just to see how fast I can handle the bosses or try new teams in the arena challenges. Big recommend!

111903866.review:
A smart and well-constructed mashup of two great genres. If you like exploration, turn based rpg combat, or deep levels of party customization, this game is absolutely worth playing.

The world is heavily interconnected and fun to poke around. Your monsters provide most of the upgrades that allow you to access new areas, which allows you the opportunity for some light sequence breaking if you explore thoroughly. The visual tells for obstacles and hidden areas are generally pretty clear, so you can tell quickly whether or not you possess the correct ability to reach any given area. In the recent major patch, they also added a nice custom map marker system to help you keep track of which places you might want to revisit in the future. Alongside this, the game also provides a handy menu option that points you to your next main objective in case you get lost.

The combat is easy to grasp but incredibly deep. You start off with very simple direct actions, and slowly throughout the game you unlock more actions and passive traits that create synergies between your monsters. By the end of the game, each of your actions is triggering multiple buffs, debuffs, heals, or extra attacks, which is incredibly satisfying to see play out. The UI is very well built to convey a lot of information that helps you predict the effectiveness of your actions so you don't get overwhelmed. The game also offers several optional challenges to really push your understanding of the system to its limits. My one personal grip with the combat is the battle scoring system, which tends to emphasize certain strategies over others.

Monster customization is also very detailed. Each monster has its own skill tree, one of two major passive buffs, equipment, and even food. All of this allows you to very thoroughly control what a monster is good at. Though a lot of the skills are shared across multiple monsters, each monster's base stats and skill tree are unique, giving each of them a clear identity. To help encourage experimentation, the game provides a few ways to boost the level of your monsters to match your highest-level monster, which eliminates the tedious grinding you tend to experience in these kinds of games. It also lets you save and load multiple team setups so you can switch back and forth easily. The one major drawback here is that it can be fairly time consuming to look through the monster skill trees and equipment lists to figure out what things go well together.

The game has solid art and character design. The monsters, which are mostly drawn from folklore, fantasy literature, and other games, have a great deal of charm and variety. The background art and music both do a solid job of conveying each region's atmosphere. The writing isn't the most sophisticated, but the main story is competently told, and the background world building (found mostly in the monster log) is pretty interesting.

Overall, I found the game extremely enjoyable, and it is one of the few games I've chosen to 100%.

It's sort of like a 2D sidescroller version of Pokemon with exploration, platforming, RPG, and puzzle elements, but actually fun... oh, and an actual story and side quests that isn't just "collecting" all the monsters or playing errand boy.

I'll start off with the good.

The 3v3 (sometimes 6v6) battles are pretty neat, as is how every single monster actually feels varied, unique, and useful at almost every stage of the game. They all have their own strengths, weaknesses, types, and so on. It's a little more complex than a "rock, paper, scissors" kind of thing. For instance, there can be a monster that's only weak to a magical fire based attack, and either neutral to or strong against all others. An interesting aspect to the battles is that you're scored and given a rating at the end which affects what drops you get, and it shows how many points you get for different things (bufss/debuffs you use, number of turns taken, synergy with attacks, combo rating, exploiting weaknesses, etc). In addition, there's a combo mechanic where the more times you hit an enemy on your turn the higher the counter rises, and the higher it rises the more damage you do, so it can pay off to do weaker attacks that deal more hits with your first two monsters, then deliver a damaging blow with your third monster. The counter resets at the end of each turn.

Every monster has it's own RPG-like skill tree, gains XP in battle (or by being part of the "active" group) which gives a skill point upon leveling up, and tiers of skills are locked behind levels. It's possible to unlock every skill for a monster by continuing to "level" it past max level where it just gains skill points.

There's a variety of equipment, levels for equipment, different kinds of food, and so on to equip or affect your monsters with, along with an option that comes up mid-game that can wildly change stats and other things.

There's just as much emphasis on active skills as there is on passive skills, and builds relying on either or a mix of both are all valid. Speaking of which, synergy not only between skills but between different monsters is set up very well. For instance I can have one monster grant a shield to all three members at the start of each round, which in turn may trigger an effect of another monster that activates upon receiving a shield.

One of my favorite things is how, unlike other games this may be compared to, your monsters actually matter outside of combat. In fact, they're absolutely essential for exploration and getting around. There's monsters that can pick you up and fly for a short time, ones that you can ride for better speed and higher jump, ones that can break open walls, ones that can cut or burn vines away, ones that help you swim, and so on and so forth. The way this works is that you have a monster following you at all times which you can use the exploration ability of (i.e. flying, destroying obstacles, etc), and you can freely swap them out for any monster you have obtained at any time without restriction.

Side note, there's also an online PvP mode you can enter once you have it unlocked. If that's not your thing, that's fine. The rest of the game is offline single player and you're not punished or miss out on rewards for not partaking in it, nor is it required to enter PvP at any time.


Now for what I don't like.

There are a couple jumps that require nearly pixel perfect precision. I don't mind challenge, but some parts are straight up ridiculous. There could also be more explanation of your monster's exploration abilities. It's touched upon once, but only for one thing for your starter. That's pretty much it. I hate sounding like a fanboy, and I'm sitting here trying to think of what else I don't like... but that's pretty much all I can think of.

A Mostly successful run at the question 'what if pokemon and symphony of the night had a love child?'  The overall world is presented very much as a 2D metroidvania with a bunch of biomes/areas to explore, but they are all filled with monsters that will drop eggs you can hatch to build up your monster battle parties.  The combat is generally a turn based 3v3 pokemon battle style affair with each creature having some specialties/skills and its own progression tree.  I do recommend speeding it up a bit in the settings menu but overall it is relatively quick and it pushes you to optimize your team balance and strategy by giving better rewards for faster/more successful combat.

Where things fray just a little bit at the edges is there really are not clear guidelines on what specific creatures do build optimal teams. Oh man, I slept on this one, and I wish I hadn't! This game was amazing! I couldn't put it down all week. 

Imagine a game that sits somewhere between Pokemon and Dragon Warrior Monsters (the Dragon Quest spin-off years ago, if you're familiar with those.) Take the elemental strengths and weaknesses and to a lesser degree, the evolutions of Pokemon. Then add the team battles from Dragon Warrior (rather than one-on-one fights -- I know Pokemon eventually did this too) and the zones full of lesser monsters to fight and recruit with "Champion" boss monsters scattered around to fight and possibly recruit as well. Now make the game you're imagining a Metroidvania RPG. Then give all the monsters a weapon slot and three accessory slots so you can custom-tailor their stats how you want them. Now give each monster four talent trees with 15-20 things in each ranging from active abilities, passive abilities, and stat boosts so you can further decide if you want them to be tanky, throw out tons of damage, buff the party, debuff the enemies, etc. AND give each monster an out of combat ability to use as you explore the world. Anything from breaking down walls to reveal secret rooms to various ways of pressing switches for puzzles, to being able to ride some of them as mounts or be carried short distances to increase your jump range. 

Pros:
-Combat is super engaging. You're constantly re-evaluating your party synergy and coming up with new strategies, and the game makes redoing your specializations really accessible, even early on. It's also very easy to catch new monsters up to your group (or even ones that you have had for a while and haven't used) if you decide you want to change things up.

-The Sanctuary setting is incredibly charming and surprisingly beautiful for what basically amounts to somewhat scaled up Terraria graphics. Each zone has its own character and feel and is genuinely fun to explore. The characters you meet along the way, while perhaps a bit cliché at times, are a fun part of the story without feeling like they're in the way.

-The monster designs follow some familiar themes at times, and at other times they go completely off the book from what you're used to in other games of this genre. Early on, I found myself gravitating towards monsters that reminded me of my favorite Pokemon, but by the end of the game, I had a very different group that I used consistently. 

Cons 
-Ok the only thing that is even remotely coming to mind, and I wouldn't even really call it a "Con" so much as something to warn people about...The music, especially in a couple of zones, is INSANELY LOUD. Simple enough to fix in audio settings (I ended up turning it down to like 10% I think) but worth noting because it wasn't consistent and when I reached the main hub of the game where you have your shops and all that, it was a bit of a surprise at first.

Bottom Line: If you like Pokemon (or other catch monsters and battle them type games), chances are, you'll love this. If you're a fan of Metroidvania games, you'll probably enjoy this too. If the idea of smashing those two genres together sounds enticing to you, go buy this game and don't let it sit in your library for a year like I did!
