110171415.review:
If you love monster catching type exploring games, I highly recommend it. You travel through interconnected maps while catching and training creatures that can help you traverse the world. It's honestly just really fun and has a lot of good design choices with a pleasant sprite work in the characters and biomes. For difficulty, it's easy enough to not be frustrating, but has enough challenge that you do have to make strategies and pick and choose how to fight enemies. It's probably a good 20 hours of playtime to beat the main story - and there's still things to do after! there's still areas I haven't explore and monsters I haven't seen.

THE PROS that separate it from other popular monster collecting/fighting games:
ACCESS TO ALL YOUR MONSTERS WHENEVER YOU WANT:
Each main fight is 3v3 and you have your team of six that each gain experience and level up/get experience in each battle. You can also choose who you want to use skills first each match, so order of them on the field doesn't matter at all! You can freely swap your main six monsters in/out to use for battles, and outside of battles, you can always reorganize your team wherever you are. In addition to your main 6, outside of battles you can use/move them around into/out of your team whenever you want. You can just equip it, try it out by swapping in, and it you don't like it, try again. No need to go anywhere or get anything to have access to all the creatures you have. Each monster also has abilities outside of battle (like letting you fly, swim, moving blocks) and you can use those abilities from any monster you have (from your 6 or your backlog) at any time at the map.

-SKILL TREES:
Each monster has three different skill trees like a lot of RPG style games for characters. Once you hatch a monster, you can see all their skills in the tree, and it tells you what each thing does. So you can choose which way to build them, and can customize how you want each critter on your roster. You have the typical health and mana with skills that others do, but you have more access to their abilities at any time in 
the battle.

-EQUIPMENT VARIETY:
You get a lot of different equipment on your guys, so you're not just laden to the standard builds/stats assigned to each monster. Each monster does have its own general stats like HP, attack, defense, etc. but the main way to increase these is through equipping. You can gets a TON of different kinda, multiple kinds of equioment that you can find and buy. And you can upgrade them with loot you collect. It adds a nice level of customization and leads to some fun additions that can completely change the way your team works.

-ALMOST NO NEED TO GRIND: 
Unlike other monster catching and training games, you can get eggs from enemies you fight and hatch them at any time. These eggs are within 2-3 levels of your main team of 6, so you don't have to fight a lot to get your new team up to level and swap/try out new beasties. You also get level badges (to increase levels from anything 2+ levels below your highest guy) and resetting stones (in case you don't like the aforementioned build you made) so you can redo your guys. These are given to you pretty liberally. As mentioned above, most stats are determined by armor/equipment that you can swap out at any time. Upgrading equipment needs materials, BUT even for those you don't need to really grind because your bestiary will tell you on each monster what its loot drops are after you find them. So no tedious fighting over and over for drops. 

SOME CONS:  to the game, or things that maybe weren't done quite as well? I honestly don't really think anything is done BADLY, just not as well as the above. You can tell there was a lot of attention put to making the different monsters fun and they don'y bog you down. Like said, if you enjoy monster catching and exploring games, I don't think any of the reasons below are any reason to not want to play. but if you're on the fence about these kind of games, these are just things to consider:

-STORY: 
It isn't bad, but a pretty basic plot that you'd expect from a game like this. The story makes sense, flows well, but it's kind of more of the same plot you'd come to expect from this kind of game. Just a pretty basic story where you start as an inexperienced kid and rise the ranks and save the world from baddies thread you've come to expect from games like this.

-CHARACTERS:
Same as above, the other allied people you encounter are a little one note and bland. Each has their own personality trait that you can see pretty much immediately and they stick to it the whole time. Not a lot of character interaction and not much depth to it.

-BACKTRACKING:
Since this is one large map, there is backtracking. This is mostly mitigated by teleporting spots in each area and an item to recall to base/items to get out of fights you didn't mean to encounter. But you'll still encounter areas/items you can't get to until you find a monster/item elsewhere to let you do it. And once you find them, you have to remember where it is and go back to it. It can be a little tedious at times to do so. 

FIGHTS CAN GET MONOTONOUS:
There's pretty great monster variety, but once you've fought a group of enemies once, you've fought them every time. From what I've seen, enemies have the same skills when you encounter them each time (there is a person later that lets you keep level of monsters the same as your own no matter where you go, this might help a bit with that) so they have the same access. You'll also often have same creatures and so you can essentially just be redoing the same strategy and attacks each time. It can get a little boring/tedious spending those turns with monsters the same with each encounter

OVERALL:
I really like this game, and if you love these kind of monster catching and fighting games, I think you'll love it, too! There was clearly a lot of thought and effort put into this game with a lot of insight into how to make a monster catching and fighting game really fun and customizeable while reducing the bad parts of them like grinding that a lot of games like this suffer from. the sprites have personality, the game is wonderful to look at and fully embraces its pixel style and there's tons of variety for organizing/changing/exploring your team options. If you're looking for a really deep and immersive game, this might not be one for you... but if you're looking for more monster catching games, this is an absolute must to pick up!

This game is like really hard pokemon mashed with a light metroidvania. You have to REALLY think through your teams synergies to progress through the game, and there is always a secret around the next corner. It is incredible to me how versatile each monsters roster is and how even with overlapping skills between monsters, each ones kit and selection of abilities feels fresh.

Some advice for beginners:
Damage is completely overrated. Control of debuffs aka removing and placing them, as well as shields will be your best friend. Shields can be equal to your max HP, so if your monster has a ton of HP, this can be a really effective tanking strategy. Also don't forget Safecast. Barrier + Channel + Shields will win you many fights. This reduces damage dealt to you, gives you extra hp to work with (Shields) and ensures you can always cast your best spells. Lastly, Shields over Healing. More HP is always better than healing your HP bar as ideally you don't want the enemy to touch your HP bar at all. Minimal healing is good, but you don't need much more.

I will say, there is some amount of disappointment to team building. Mass debuff removal and shields are essentially a must for every team. This does limit team building to some extend. I could also be completely wrong and built it wrong, but damage outside of slow teams using Age stacking felt like they just really could not cut it and output the needed damage. Either way, I could not put this game down from start to finish. So much to love about this game. The art style, music, dungeon designs are all top notch. I love pokemon, this is not pokemon outside of collecting monsters and turn based combat. It is much harder. That said, I love how you have all 3 of your monsters working together and the teamwork between them is lovely. It also makes or breaks the harder fights of the game. I would highly recommend this to anyone who likes hard strategy games and collectables. Easy 9/10 :)

Greatly enjoyed this game.

[list]
[*] It's a monster collection/battling game with around 100 monster types, and each one has an individual skill tree. Somehow every single monster looks like it would be potentially useful in some sort of endgame setup, and you often have multiple ways to build an individual monster.
[*] Most standard battles are simple to beat, but since your rewards depend on performance ranking, you're still encouraged to think about the most efficient way to win. The "boss battles" however ramp up in difficulty until they really test your team-building. While everything appears usable, just slapping together any six monsters and attacking enemy weakness will not work, and the game instead favors things like effective utilization of non-attacking moves/effects, a strong central theme, and/or abilities that synergize with each other. 
[*] The game also makes it so that any new interesting monsters you find are quick to incorporate to a team. Every new monster hatches only a couple levels below your best one, and you only need to feed it a couple food items and swap over some equipment for it to be essentially on par with the rest of your party. Level-up items that let monsters catch up to your highest-leveled one are also infinitely buyable.
[*] The metroidvania aspects take a backseat, but do allow for some freedom in the order you progress through the game. The game also essentially levels along the player, so as long as one roughly fights every new monster group once, no new encounters should have the player either over- or underleveled.
[/list]

Overall, if you like RPGs with a large degree of customizability, prefer to use strategies other than just spamming attacks in turn-based combat, and are not afraid of some difficulty, then I heavily recommend this game.

I want to like this game so much.  It does so much almost right.  The non-linear game, the team building, the battle system...they're all so close to working in a way that's truly enjoyable.

But every one of them falls flat in a way that doesn't seem like it's improving but is rather getting worse as I go on.  I'm going to go from most frustrating to least frustrating here to help prioritize.

The biggest gripe I have is that wild battles/guardian fights and fighting other keepers are fundamentally different to the point it's become extremely frustrating because they take different teams.  Wild battles and guardian fights focus on a star rating system.  The faster you kill them and the more health your team has left when you succeed, the better your star rating, and more stars equals more rewards (5* a guardian fight for an egg of that guardian).  This encourages building a team that hits hard, fast, and often, and is where I think the game is at its best - many monsters cover this well, and allows for the flexibility the game boasts to shine through.

Keeper fights though...the farther you get in the game, the more these require a very specific kind of team, and that is very inflexible.  Usually a team that cleanses debuffs well and applies their own rather than focusing on the damage.  They become fights of attrition where hitting hard and fast is just straight up not a strategy.  So what this means for you is you'll have a team of monsters that you go through the overworld with and try to build around the star system, only to get stonewalled by a keeper fight and need to go grind up a different team that can out-attrition them.  It's a jarring shift and is my biggest gripe with the game - I did not like needing to bench the roughly dozen monsters I had built up to handle different kinds of fights under the star system to grind up a handful of goblins which out-sustained the keeper at the top of the Sun Tower, for example.  It goes against the "build what you like" model and the two types of battles don't mesh at all.  If they had picked one and stuck with it, it would be so much better, even if that meant not having as many "viable" monsters.  As is it feels like they made all the monsters, made one battle style, then decided they needed variety for the sake of the monsters that didn't work well under system 1 and made system 2.

Next up on the frustration is the RNG gatekeeping.  The exploration side of a metroidvania is to find the one room with the new powerup you need and then go use it wherever you can.  This is still the case sometimes in Monster Sanctuary and it works well when that's the roadblock.  Just as often though, it's a monster ability you're lacking, and in that case you're now subject to RNG.  Farm the monster fights, hope you did well enough in the star system for decent drops, and then hope you get the egg you need to get the next ability to move on.  It brings the game to a grinding halt, quite literally, especially since monsters only respawn when you clear four other rooms or use a consumable to bring them back.  So if there's 3 rooms with the correct kind of monster, that means, travel time between rooms excluded, you're not actively working on your goal 25% of the time.  (Also I understand that they didn't want to give the starters amazing abilities but it feels really contrived that the Eagle familiar can't figure out how to use greater fly when it's supposed to be the embodiment of the air).

Finally, a minor gripe, but one that seems to be mirrored in other reviews, the platforming is fairly minimal, which feels off for a metroidvania title.  It's a minor thing and I'm not giving the review its thumbs down for that, but I would like to note it.

Overall, Monster Sanctuary is a ton of fun early on.  I really like the character designs, the monsters are more classic JRPG monsters than something like Pokemon or TemTem, but they're charming and I like them on the whole.  Music is solid if really really loud (even when turning it most of the way down in the settings) and the plot has been genuinely interesting if fairly bare bones.  The non-linearity is amazingly well done too, with monsters' levels being set based on how much of the map you've explored rather than area C being level 15 all the time, in case you go and do areas D E and F first.  But the core gameplay loops struggle to be consistent and ultimately causes a lot more frustration than enjoyment...I've tried to play this three times now, and two of the times I've stopped was because of frustration with the core loops not being consistent.  It's so close to being a great game, but the lack of consistency in what battles gauge as being "successful" and the forced RNG drop grinding for some of your powerups just keeps making me put it down after a fairly short time playing it.  I'm making progress each time, but not having much fun doing it, so I can't recommend it.

108040847.review:
I've thought about it for a bit after beating the game and, no, I can't really recommend this game.

The biggest issue is that it is not what it is advertised as - a cross between pokemon and metroidvania. It's not a metroidvania because the metroidvania aspect of the game is so bare-bones and basically just a substitute for the top-down overworld view of the older pokemon games. Rare is the instance it takes actual skill to accomplish anything in the overworld. The platforming is basic, never challenging, and mostly seems to serve as something to do between the battles. The pokemon-like aspect is also kind of a lie too, because this game lacks the charm and personality that pokemon tends to have. The designs aren't very interesting, for one, even the late-game ones look like... generic JPRG enemies, for all intents and purposes, and as well fighting them just feels like fighting stat machines, not "oh god another wobuffet" or "haha a stunfisk nice" or "ooh finally a ralts" they're just. Enemies. The rest of the aesthetic doesn't have charm either - every area looks fine but it's the most visually basic version of its archetype - grasslands, cave, beach, snowy mountain, etc. and the music is... I just do not like this game's soundfont, I guess, but it all sounds so dry to me. There were maybe one or two area themes I liked and that was about it, the battle theme gets so old because it never, ever changes, even bosses and trainer battles (er, sorry, "keeper battles") have one song each that only rarely changes for particularly important encounters (read: like two or three times total, I think). 

So strip away all the metroidvania exploration, all the charm and charisma, and what you have is a very technical JPRG that's mostly based on buffs, buffs, and more buffs. Like sure, try to build a team based on dealing raw damage. You won't, because they forgot to balance DoT effects, to the point where DoTs were dealing more damage that I could manage with standard attacks. And thus every fight devolved into the same loop. Set up buffs, regen, shields, get my infectious poison and burn on every mob, stall for time until they died, maybe attack every so often to speed up the process if I have a chance to. Druid Oak, Vasuki, Stolby, my three-piece disaster team that completely tore through the last 40ish% of the game by themselves to the point where I stopped even using my other monsters entirely. Hey, if it works, it works. The alternative is suffering and losing fights over and over until you sneak out a win, because there's so many systems going on all the time and so many things to keep track of that can all be undermined by an unlucky crit or a miss (evasion is the worst invention of JRPG-kind and should never, ever be implemented, if I attack, I don't miss, okay? It's that easy.)

Like, there was a period where it was kind of fun to play with teams and try to find good builds, but that also slowed down the pace of the game and often lead to worse builds that did less damage less consistently. I almost swapped out Stolby for a Rainbow Blob when I got one of those but, no, it was worse, why change my strategy when my strategy works against literally everything? I'm sure all the speculative teamcrafting and min-maxing is fun for a certain kind of person, but this game is already pretty long for what it is, at some point I was just ready to see it end.

Dealing with overworld encounters is so easy and banal that, honestly, they barely feel impactful for anything other than testing out a build, yet there's dozens per area and they respawn way faster than you'd ever want them to. Even the fastest battles will take a minute or two and the longer ones upwards of five, with no actual risk of losing or being challenged, but you need to fight them or else you're going to be underlevelled and underskilled for the keeper fights! I did at one point in the early game have to grind a bit to be able to deal with the first keeper fight, because it comes out of the blue and demolishes you if you're not prepared (you won't be, because nothing else has challenged you at all up to this point). There's no middle ground between "easy as pie" and "frustrating and luck-based" until you find that winning strat, at which point, again, why change it?

I've seen people complain about the final boss gauntlet of three fights (actually two fights, guys, you can leave the room and come back after the first one to set a checkpoint) and like, yeah, I guess I did forfeit like two turns into the second time my first go around because i messed up setting up and ended up with one of my monsters dead, but because I had The Strategy in place once I did get set up I had no issues whatsoever, and the final final boss is a piece of cake compared to the average keeper fight, too. So the game ends anticlimactically. I guess it feels good to not struggle, but the story wasn't particularly engaging, either. I'm just stubborn.

If you really like technical, teambuilding RPGs, I guess this game is for you, and for what it's worth the systems in play are very deep and interesting to play around with, it's not really a -bad- game, more of a middle ground that steam doesn't offer, but I'm not the right kind of person for this game and I kind of regret getting suckered into playing it by what it claimed to be on the surface. Oh well.

107695034.review:
Gimmicky combat that requires knowing specific combinations of monster skills to get anywhere. Don't go in blind if you don't want to spend a day grinding up a team that looks good on paper, only for it to fall apart before whatever keeper battle or champion monster you are stuck on. It's not so bad with champions, but keeper fights are a torture, and you barely get to leave a room before you are forced to fight another one in the Abandoned Tower (you get sick of them way before that, though). I'm no expert on this game's combat system, I can't even get a single monster that levitates big rocks, but the overabundance of skills that inflict random debuffs (or randomly inflict pre-defined ones), grant random buffs (some of which raise your evasion), cure random debuffs, remove or steal random buffs from enemies, lower the enemy's, or, sometimes, your own monster's accuracy, randomly trigger extra hits and, of course, score criticals makes me suspect that the whole system is actually a barely playable mess. Good luck estimating how much damage your team will be dealing and how much it can take with that in mind, and that's before you account for the combo multiplier that affects the power of your and your opponents' attacks, healing and shields.

Having to switch monsters all the time while exploring the overworld gets annoying quickly, especially if you also use a riding monster to save a few seconds on the parts where your path isn't obstructed. The only exploration ability that you get to use normally is double jump, for everything else you must wade through your ever growing list of duplicate monster abilities. In a good metroidvania tradition, most, if not all obstacles can only be cleared in a pre-defined way, so invisible platforms, large rocks and equally large pressure plates are only there so that you can add them to your "To backtrack" list. You aren't sneaking past them early.

In case just doing those things being unsatisfying was not enough, your reward for defeating most of the story mode keepers is a random reward box, and the majority of the chests found in the world contain regular upgrade materials (or, sometimes, random reward boxes).

The game's music is bland, and is sometimes grating to listen to, and so, of course, its soundtrack is sold separately, why not. The story is uninspired, and it only makes the keepers even more annoying and makes you respect the champion monsters more, since at least they don't say anything stupid before or after you defeat them.

This is how it felt playing it on normal mode without consulting any guides. Maybe it would have been less frustrating if I picked Casual like a baby, or copied somebody else's walkthrough and built a correct team instead of trying to figure the game out.
